Same as any of the gardens visited in other cities of japan,this garden is good for walking around n away from the crowd...good scenic spots if you are into photography and the recent half bloom sakura may add some colours to your photos and take time to admire the different

Ohori Park is a modest-sized urban park noted for its lake. Though there is little you could say is spectacular about it, all-in-all it is a pleasant stop. The lake is scenic and small enough that you can comfortably walk around it. It is even shorter to do as most people do and
A nice walk and a great way to take in the quieter side of the city and right next to the castle ruins if you are looking for something more to explore.

We only managed to walk part of the park and visited the Japanese Garden there. The Japanese Garden is not very big but smartly and beautifully designed with trees and waters (ponds, small waterfalls). Worth a visit if you've got time in Hakata.

I alighted at Ohorikoen subway station and took Exit 3 to reach Ohori Park for my evening run last week (mid Feb 2015). I ran around the circumference of the lake which was once a moat of the Fukuoka Castle, and visited the castle ruins; ran passed the Fukuoka Art Museum,
A beautiful park in the middle of the city. We go here every morning for a run, to have a coffee and in the summer to watch the fireworks. Also a great place for people watching!

Ohori Park is close from home. Just walking. Jogging. Running. Lots of pleasures this park. Various birds on the lake. Lake surrounded by various trees. If you coming this park. You say "That's good, that'll do" Maybe I think so.
Very nice park to stroll around and relax. Beautiful architecture surrounded by nature. Bring something to eat while you sit on one of the many benches.

Our visit was in winter, so I'm sure with leaves on the trees and flowers blooming the park would be even more pretty. The place is absolutely huge with a 'pond' (it's massive with multiple islands and pretty bridges), restaurant, castle remains, sports areas, walking tracks
The castle ruins are quite unimpressive, but the bridges, toris and the view are very beautiful. I visited in the winter, nevertheless it was enjoyable!

This is a nice central park for the local to jog, cycling and relax. The track covers around the lake, which gives a nice view. Many local came to jog and cycling even at night. If you enjoy doing what the local do, this is a good place to do your morning or evening

We stayed at hotel Sunline Fukuoka and the park was just a 5 to 10 minutes walk across the road from the hotel. There are many entrances to the park. From our entry point, we walked through a playground area before reaching the park on a Saturday morning (6 Dec 2014). There were
Lucky to be there in Autumn and see the trees in colour. Lots of interesting items and areas, particularly the waterfalls.

Ohori Park was one of our stops on the Fukuoka Bike Tour. It is a beautiful park surrounding a lake. There is a 2 km walking, jogging, and biking path around the lake. On Sunday morning, there were a lot of people out walking, jogging and biking. There were also several

Autumn foliage was fabulous. The lake area is simply peaceful. Only locals come here to jog or walk. Off the beaten path. Nearby there's a Japanese garden (south near the art museum). Don't miss it - autumn or otherwise. Entry is not expensive - 200 yen. There's tea an
Loved exploring the ruins of fukuoka castle nearby~ and it was still autumn-ish!! the various shades of green, oranges and reds made it really beautiful!

Hit regularly by locals for leisure/sports activities, Ohori Park is a nice spot if you want to take a break or do some sport activities. Just a few minutes sitting lakeside watching the ducks swimming can make your mind go away from the city. The Starbucks is not invasive,

The Ohori park is basically a place for relaxation and exercise. Benches are installed surrounding the pond and a path for strolling or jogging. I visited this place last September 2014 as it was listed as one of the recommended sites to visit in the Fukuoka visitor's pamphlet

You can spend hours strolling or just sit and watch the people go by. Many bring their pets along for walks. You can see doggies in bicycle baskets, on leash or on doggy prams. There is a Starbucks where you can have a bite and a cuppa. I visited the Japanese Garden(for a small
Big, tasteful, good walking route, lots of koi and ducks. Families with kids and couples, older joggers can all enjoy. Worth several hours of your day.
This park has a great lake, is relaxing stay and take a look to the people passing by, birds flying around, boats; good place for sports too. has a japanese garden and art museum.
Green with nice walking spaces and a lake in the middle. Lot of peace and quiet. Thumbs up, great place to spend an evening or noon.
the park was very pretty even at night. There was a fairly large play area for children as well and delicious icecream in the vending machine.

This beautiful huge park is reminiscent of NYC's Central Park. We didn't have enough time to walk the entire park but we did explore some playgrounds and enjoyed the sunflowers that lined the pathways. It's pretty and peaceful here with lots to see and do, the perfect mix!
Nice location to see trees and enjoying walk in morning or late afternoon, if you want some cup of coffee you can stop by at starbucks that have very nice spot in this park

This park reminded me of Central Park. There's a lot of activity around but the park is peaceful but there are a good number of people using the wonderful facilities. There are walking paths and trails but also boats to be rented. I walked in the center island bridge and enjoyed
if you want to relax a bit, come to this park! They don't hv too many sightseeing points but will make u feel comfortable to stay there!

The Ohori Park was very beautiful and the island and bridges that cross the middle of the lake are a great way to see the park or to just sit back and relax. There were plenty of people riding in boats, driving boats, and just relaxing when I visited.

Honestly, it still puzzles me why this is the #1 attraction in Fukuoka. Maybe it is because we did not visit this when the cherry blossoms are blooming. We have been to many parks in Japan and this is by far, the least attractive. Very ordinary, in fact. The biggest saving

I love this park! I stayed in Fukuoka on a business trip for around a month and visited this park on the weekends. There are cycle tracks and jogging lanes around the beautiful lake for people who wanted to get some exercise. There were peaceful benches in quiet spots to sit
Taking a walk around Ohori park viewing the Cherry Blossom was relaxing and there were a few places to visit other than the Ohori Park, like the castle ruins and the museum..
Very good park and have tipical Japanese sights. there's a museum near this park and very easy to access from hakata station and fukuoka airport.

This city recreational park is designed around a large lake, with a long bridge across the middle of the lake, and a wide space for people to walk/run/cycle/amble around the lake. It's got an ambience of peacefulness and content, with so many people indulged in relaxing and/or

Very pretty park with "lake" and island. Lots of locals enjoying the outdoors and Cherry Blossoms! Easy, safe, pleasant walk through park and made a nice early morning activity before most businesses opened. Easy access by subway.
Beautiful walk through this manicured garden. Many people walking and using the running track. Track crosses over a few islands with attractive bridges, good for photo opportunities.

Have breakfast at Bakery Kitchen Raggruppi (http://www.raggruppi.net/) before taking a stroll in the beautiful Ohori Park. Check out the Japanese Garden as well if you have some cash to spare (¥200 per person)
I went there for a short walk around. It is peaceful and nice. There is a starbucks shop in the park as well so I stopped for a cup of coffee there to see people walking, jogging and talking.

This is a great park. It has huge lily ponds. Just beautiful. The city has many functions, including the largest fireworks show in the area during the summer. Well worth the visit to see. It is also an original location for the area baseball field.
Great for a stroll, very peaceful. Would recommend bringing a book and reading along the waterfront or in the pavilion in the middle of the lake!

the US Embassy is just near by. lots of nice flowers in Spring and winter time lots of people walking doing their exercise. Cool place to be for a nice spring picnic. Took my family there via the subway and have fond memories there.
Loved this park just to go for a stroll and relax. Loads of turtles in the ponds and excellent spots for photographs!

Ohori has a nice track around the lake that is split between joggers and walkers. My kids learned to ride there bikes there. The fireworks display in August draws a lot of participants and really helps give you a taste of festival life in Japan. Now they have a Starbucks

Ohori Park is good for taking leisurely walks and it is easily accessible via the subway (Ohori-koen stop). I went in early Nov, and the trees were not yet in fall foilage. There is a Japanese garden (a fee is needed) within Ohori Park. It's quite a nice place, though a bit

After a hearty lunch and a busy morning, Ohori park provides the relaxing venue with its grandiose lake in the center. Strolling across the long bridge to the island at the center of the lake proved very relaxing and pleasurable to the senses. What surprised us most were these

a lovely park to walk around large lake in the middle and some lovely Japanese bridges to cross there is also a Japanese garden to walk around which is so beautiful. look out for the jumping fish in the lake they leap right up out of the water
Great place on a sunny day to go for a jog, walk or bike ride. We visited here on our first day in Fukuoka on rented bikes traveling from Tenjin to Fukuoka Tower.

This is worth visiting for a couple of hours, say a morning stroll, around the lake with a visit to the Fukuoka Art Museum that sits within the grounds. It is like a mini Hyde Park and Serpentine Lake, with pine cones to collect (rather than conkers). There's also a very

Beautiful park with a big pond, where we can enjoy boat or just relax on a bench. A walking trail around the pond is about 2km, good for a casual walk. Starbucks in the park is a good stop when tired a little.

The park is very beautiful and is a nice place to relax. The castle ruins are literally right next to the park. There is a Starbucks in the park as well as many cultural structures. If you are nearby the park, I would strongly recommend going there.

This is safe park with 2km jogging course. You can enjoy jogging and walking 24 hours. American Consulate is located near by many polices are guarding around this park. They have coffee shops and restaurants in the park you can take lunch or coffee break. Close to subway station

Ohori Park was the largest park I saw in Japan, and contained the most beautiful traditional Japanese garden I saw (we travelled in Tokyo, Kyoto, Osaka, and Kumamoto besides Fukuoka). The park is steps from the subway, and very large. You can walk around the pond or on a

The beauty and ambiance was great! The park is manmade and has a big lake where one can go boating on, and the path around the lake is filled with people walking, jogging, or bicycling. It is easily accessible by public bus or subway transportation. In the spring, there are

The weather was great in late May when I visited the park. It was easily accessible by subway. Local Japanese were there to walk, boat, run, exercise, etc. Nothing interesting. Just a pleasant place in the middle of a busy city. After walking around the park and building up

Really nice park cool old ruins of the castle. Definitely worth visit if you like old castle ruins. Quite a good bit of walking to see the whole park though. If get to the top of the castle site there is a great view of the city.
Ohori Park is a spacious park with a lake where you can do boating. It is a lovely park to relax in together with the locals.

Really cooling in big city like Fukuoka you still find the place like this rally cooling, the people use the place for relaxing or get some exercise by jogging, Even in winter time is amazing on summer will be more beautiful with sakura flower around the park, They have

It was grand, historic and felt so holy. I can spend hours sitting here and doing nothing else. I have heard a lot about firework festival here but haven't got chance to see it. I hope to experience it on my next visit.
Gorgeous place with lots of nice boats to ride. Not too crowded and very relaxing. If this were in Tokyo you'd be fighting off the crowds with a stick.

enjoyed the visit to this nice park. Went there to see the Cherry Blossoms in bloom and enjoyed walking around. Was crowded but still peaceful than the hubbub of the Hakata City. Take a moment out of your schedule to walk around here when you are in Hakata.

This was the very first thing that I did when I got to Fukuoka. It's a very short distance from the subway. Literally, you walk up the stairs and the park is on the right. The castle ruins are great beside the rows of cherry blossoms, tons of great photo spots. This is probably
Definitely a must see while in Fukuoka. Take a stroll, jog or a bike ride through. You will not regret a second you spend here.

Short walking distance from subway station stop. Park is big, with layout shown in maps and signs around the park. We weren't able to get to the castle ruins, but the cherry blossom part of the park was lovely with lots of people around enjoying hanami season.
Large open park in the middle of Hakata. Great place to stroll. Don't forget to visit a Japanese garden nearby
You can see Ohori on the same day as a trip to the castle. It may be nothing special, just a park, but a nice way to relax and see the locals out and about and relaxed.

The park is a real treat, certainly worth a visit in conjunction with Fukuoka castle ruins. It can be romantic, but on this particular Sunday it was full of runners (a race was being held). Still, nice people watching.

It's a park like anywhere else. Maybe more interesting in April/May during the cherry blossom season. But to be honnest: Fukuoka and any other cities in this area are really boring and got no or really less special things to see. Fukuoka looks like any other boring european

This is a beautiful peaceful park that is used mainly by the locals for family walks and an energetic run after work in the evenings. The location is serene, enviroment green and lush. We sat at this waterside and enjoyed a tremendous evening of quiet and peace.
Ohori park offers some quiet monents to have a walk when Tenjin and Hakata areas are full of people and everything is crowded.

This is a nice quite park very peaceful. Very nice in march not many people and the traditional garden was also peaceful i was the only one of 2 people in the whole garden. Its a nice place to relax if you had a busy day :)

I was around Ohori park during the Hanami period (visited in March 2010) - the remarkable beauty of blossoming trees (not only cherry trees) was underlined by the remnants of Fukuoka castle (just a few walls and a gate actually) and together it worked perfectly. Easily

We stopped here during a visit to Fukuoka. This is a beautiful walking park with a Japanese Garden. It was quite humid on this day but the walk along the lake, through the island was enjoyable and peaceful. The Swan paddle boats are fun too without being to strenuous.

The park is a wonderful escape from the city. The park itself is great and has a 2km jogging path around it. Walk over the bridge and through the forest area for some peace and quite. For a real escape, go to the Japanese Garden that is attached to the park. It was truly a

If you are tied of the shopping streets at Tenjin, you can spend a few hours walking around the lake in the middle of the park. This park seems to copy a part of the Summer Palace in Beijing but it is of a much smaller scale. We had a nice stroll through the bridges and islands

A lovely escape from the hustle and bustle of the city. Walking/run around the pristine lake or take a hike up to some of the older preserved relics. Many families, locals, and tourists come here. Would do so again!

A beautiful park and a great place to run with its 2k jogging path. The lake is serene and you don't even feel like you're in the city when you're in the park. There is a Starbucks located right in the middle of the park that is a great place to people watch and have coffee.
It is very big and nice park. I walked there about three hours. Especially I liked a lake with convenient ways around and across water.
Its design is carboncopy on a chinese park. Good for running, picnic and relaxing. Take your bicicle or rollerblades. As a plus, the Fukuoka Museum is on a side of the park.
The park is amazing. It's a beautiful park. Lots of places to sit and relax. If you have kids, there is a park at one end.
Didn't explore the whole park but did spend some time with the kids at the playground. The peddle boats are nice and relaxing and kids love to steer.
If you are long walks, jogging, cycling or just like enjoy green spaces within a city, this is the place to go.Also an awesome place to take the kids for a family day out.
This park has an entrance fee of 190 yen but it is well worth it. Very Japan, beautiful, crisp. We really enjoyed our stroll.

When visting the ruins of Fukuoka Castle take a nice stroll in Ohori park around the lake. A beautiful park especially during cherry blossom time. There is a nice Starbucks where you can sit and enjoy a cup and watch the scenery

We took a stroll around to Ohori Park and sat in the Starbucks for about an hour, having a chat over a coffee and watching the fitness enthusiasts running around. It's a great place to sit outside if the weather is decent. I would really like to visit the art museum in the park
A great park which is easy to miss. A walk around or over the bridge to the little island is a must, look out for the giant fish lurking in the lake!
Great place for a stroll, or a jog. Good cafe as well.

I fell in love with the park when I saw the blossom of sakura and plum. Additionally, the location of the park is very cozy. The public transportation is very convenient though parking is very expensive.

This park is the biggest park in Fukuoka, but it's just park except spring. In spring, you can see very beautiful cherry blossom in this park. If you visit Fukuoka in spring, you should go this park!!!

Ohori Park is a beautiful park surrounding a large lake. It is an excellent place for astroll or a picnic. There are convenience stores nearby. There is also a restaurant in the park. To get here take the subway to Ohori-koen stop. Within the park grounds there is a Japanese

If you wanna take a break or do sports in Fukuoka I'd reccomend Ohori Koen. The park is great for picnics with friends, taking walks and especially for skating and jogging. You also see a lot of people going for a walk with their dogs or playing frisbee and soccer. What I also
google: One of the best park I had the chance to visit. I live near by and I don't get tired of it. It's connected to other beautiful sites like the castle ruins and picnic fields. The lac is stunning, turtles, fishes, birds, landscape, it goes all …

Go early if you wanna grab a drink from Starbucks! Otherwise take your time walking around. It can be a perfect date with friends or your significant other! Not sure about other times, but in Feb the wind was crazy strong which made it …

My first time checking this place out. I wanted to a couple years ago, but this time, I was able too. 

Very huge lake where tons of people go jogging. But there is an "island" with connecting bridges on each side and you can walk through the lake. 

Pretty cool and gorgeous place.

Great place to watch birds, feed koi fishes, exercise, and spend time with your pet or kids! the park is really huge with a full running track that goes around the entire park. There’s a big playground and cafes that allow you to have lunch with your pet! My favorite park in Fukuoka

text.wiki:
Fukuoka (福岡市, Fukuoka-shi, pronounced [ɸɯ̥kɯokaꜜɕi]) is the capital city of Fukuoka Prefecture, situated on the northern shore of the Japanese island of Kyushu. It is the most populous city on the island, followed by Kitakyushu. It is the largest city and metropolitan area west of Keihanshin. The city was designated on April 1, 1972, by government ordinance. Greater Fukuoka, with a population of 2.5 million people (2005 census), is part of the heavily industrialized Fukuoka–Kitakyushu zone.
As of 2015, Fukuoka is Japan's sixth largest city, having passed the population of Kobe. In July 2011, Fukuoka surpassed the population of Kyoto. Since the founding of Kyoto in 794, this marks the first time that a city west of the Kinki region has a larger population than Kyoto. In ancient times, however, the area near Fukuoka, the Chikushi region, was thought by some historians to have possibly been even more influential than the Yamato region.


== Pre-history ==
Exchanges from the continent and the Northern Kyushu area date as far back as Old Stone Age. It has been thought that waves of immigrants arrived in Northern Kyushu from mainland Asia. Several Kofun exist.


== History ==

Fukuoka was sometimes called the Port of Dazaifu (大宰府), 15 km (9 mi) southeast from Fukuoka. Dazaifu was an administrative capital in 663 A.D., but a historian proposed that a prehistoric capital was in the area. Ancient texts, such as the Kojiki, Kanyen (found in Dazaifu) and archaeology confirm this was a very critical place in the founding of Japan. Some scholars claim that it was the first place outsiders and the Imperial Family set foot, but like many early Japan origin theories, it remains contested. Central Fukuoka is sometimes still referred as Hakata which is the name of the central ward.
In 923, the Hakozaki-gū in Fukuoka was transferred from Daibu-gū in Daibu (大分), 16 km (10 mi) northeast from Dazaifu, the origin of Usa Shrine and established as a branch of the Usa Shrine at Fukuoka. In Ooho (大保), 15 km (9 mi) south from Dazaifu, there are remains of a big ward office with a temple, because in ancient East Asia, an emperor must have three great ministries (大宰, 大傳 and 大保). In fact, there is a record in Chinese literature that a king of Japan sent a letter in 478 to ask the Chinese emperor's approval for employing three ministries. In addition, remains of the Korokan (鴻臚館, Government Guest House) were found in Fukuoka underneath a part of the ruins of Fukuoka Castle.


=== Mongol invasions (1274–1281) ===

Kublai Khan of the Mongol Empire turned his attention towards Japan starting in 1268, exerting a new external pressure on Japan with which it had no experience. Kublai Khan first sent an envoy to Japan to make the Shogunate acknowledge Khan's suzerainty. The Kamakura shogunate refused. Mongolia repeatedly sent envoys thereafter, each time urging the Shogunate to accept their proposal, but to no avail.
In 1274, Kublai Khan mounted an invasion of the northern part of Kyushu with a fleet of 900 ships and 33,000 troops, including troops from Goryeo on the Korean Peninsula. This initial invasion was compromised by a combination of incompetence and severe storms. After the invasion attempt of 1274, Japanese samurai built a stone barrier 20 km (12 mi) in length bordering the coast of Hakata Bay in what is now the city of Fukuoka. The wall, 2–3 metres in height and having a base width of 3 metres, was constructed between 1276 and 1277, and was excavated in the 1930s.
Kublai sent another envoy to Japan in 1279. At that time, Hōjō Tokimune of the Hōjō clan (1251–1284) was the Eighth Regent. Not only did he decline the offer, but he beheaded the five Mongolian emissaries after summoning them to Kamakura. Infuriated, Kublai organized another attack on Fukuoka Prefecture in 1281, mobilizing 140,000 soldiers and 4,000 ships. The Japanese defenders, numbering around 40,000, were no match for the Mongols and the invasion force made it as far as Dazaifu, 15 km (9 mi) south of the city of Fukuoka. However, the Japanese were again aided by severe weather, this time by a typhoon that struck a crushing blow to the Mongolian troops, thwarting the invasion.
It was this typhoon that came to be called the Kamikaze (Divine Wind), and was the origin of the term Kamikaze used to indicate suicide attacks by military aviators of the Empire of Japan against Allied naval vessels during World War II.


=== Formation of the modern city (1889) ===

Fukuoka was formerly the residence of the powerful daimyō of Chikuzen Province, and played an important part in the medieval history of Japan. The renowned temple of Tokugawa Ieyasu in the district was destroyed by fire during the Boshin War of 1868. 
The modern city was formed on April 1, 1889, with the merger of the former cities of Hakata and Fukuoka. Historically, Hakata was the port and merchant district, and was more associated with the area's culture and remains the main commercial area today. On the other hand, the Fukuoka area was home to many samurai, and its name has been used since Kuroda Nagamasa, the first daimyō of Chikuzen Province, named it after his birthplace in Okayama Prefecture and the "old Fukuoka" is the main shopping area, now called Tenjin.
When Hakata and Fukuoka decided to merge, a meeting was held to decide the name for the new city. Hakata was initially chosen, but a group of samurai crashed the meeting and forced those present to choose Fukuoka as the name for the merged city. However, Hakata is still used to refer to the Hakata area of the city and, most famously, to refer to the city's train station, Hakata Station, and dialect, Hakata-ben.


=== 20th century ===
1903: Fukuoka Medical College, a campus associated with Kyoto Imperial University, is founded. In 1911, the college is renamed Kyushu Imperial University and established as a separate entity.
1910: Fukuoka streetcar service begins. (The service ran until 1979.)
1929: Flights commence along the Fukuoka-Osaka-Tokyo route.
1945: Fukuoka was firebombed on June 19, with the attack destroying 21.5 percent of the city's urban area.
1947: First Fukuoka Marathon.
1951: Fukuoka airport opens.
1953: Fukuoka Zoo opens.
1975: The city absorbed the town of Sawara.
1981: Subway commences service.
1988: Osaka's pro baseball team, the Nankai Hawks, are moved to Fukuoka and renamed the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks (renamed the Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks in 2004).
1989: Asian-Pacific Exposition is held.
1997: The 30th annual meeting of the Asian Development Bank was held in Fukuoka.


=== 21st century ===
2005: Fukuoka subway Nanakuma Line started operations.
2014: Selected as the National Strategic Zone for "global startups & job creation" by the Japanese government.
2020: City affected by Covid-19.


== Geography ==
Fukuoka is bordered on three sides by mountains, surrounds Hakata Bay and opens on the north to the Genkai Sea.
It is located 1,100 km (684 mi) from Tokyo.


=== Climate ===
Fukuoka has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen: Cfa), hot and humid summers, and relatively mild winters. The city also sees on average about 1,600 mm (63 in) of precipitation per year, with a stretch of more intense precipitation between the months of June and September. Along with much of the prefecture, Fukuoka City has a moderate climate with an annual average temperature of 16.3 °C (61 °F), average humidity of 70% and 1,811 annual daylight hours. Roughly 40% of the year is cloudy.
Winter temperatures rarely drop below 0 °C (32 °F) and it rarely snows, though light rain does fall on most days if not as consistently as on the Sea of Japan side of Honshu. Spring is warm and sunnier, with cherry blossoms appearing in late March or early April. The rainy season (tsuyu) lasts for approximately six weeks through June and July, during which time the humidity is very high and temperatures hover between 25 °C (77 °F) and 30 °C (86 °F). Summers are humid and hot, with temperatures peaking around 37 °C (99 °F). Autumn, often considered to be Fukuoka's best season, is mild and dry, though the typhoon season runs between August and September.


=== Earthquakes ===

Fukuoka is not as seismically active as many other parts of Japan, but does experience occasional earthquakes. The most powerful recent earthquake registered a lower 6 of maximum 7 of the Japanese intensity scale and hit at 10:53 am local time on March 20, 2005, killing one person and injuring more than 400. The epicentre of the earthquake was in the Genkai Sea along a yet-undiscovered extension of the Kego fault that runs through the centre of Fukuoka. Genkai island, a part of Nishi-ku, was the most severely damaged by the earthquake and almost all island residents were forced to evacuate. Aftershocks continued intermittently throughout the following weeks as construction crews worked to rebuild damaged buildings throughout the city. Traditional Japanese houses, particularly in the areas of Daimyo and Imaizumi, were the most heavily damaged and many were marked for demolition, along with several apartment buildings. Insurance payments for damages were estimated at approximately 15.8 billion yen.A similar quake, with an intensity of 5+, also occurred one month later on April 20, 2005.
Fukuoka's major Kego fault runs northwest to southeast, roughly parallel to Nishitetsu's Ōmuta train line, and was previously thought to be 22 km (14 mi) long. It is estimated to produce earthquakes as strong as magnitude 7 at the focus approximately once every 15,000 years. If the focus were located at a depth of 10 km (6 mi), this would translate to an earthquake of a lower-6 magnitude (similar to the March 20, 2005 earthquake) in downtown Fukuoka if it were the epicenter. The probability of an earthquake along the known length of the Kego fault occurring within 30 years was estimated at 0.4% prior to the March 20, 2005 earthquake, but this probability has been revised upwards since. Including the new extension out into the Genkai Sea, the Kego fault is now thought to be 40 km (25 mi) long.
Following reports that the city has only prepared for earthquakes up to a magnitude of 6.5, several strong aftershocks renewed fears that the quakes might cause the portion of the Kego fault that lies under the city to become active again, leading to an earthquake as big as, or bigger than, the March 20 quake.


== Wards ==
Fukuoka has 7 wards (ku).


== Demographics ==
As of November 2018, the city had an estimated population of 1,581,527 and a population density of 4,515.64 persons per km². The total area is 343.39 square kilometres (132.58 sq mi). Fukuoka is Japan's youngest major city and has Japan's fastest growing population. Between December 2012 and December 2017, the proportion of foreign-born residents increased faster than any other major city in Japan, including Tokyo.There were 171 homeless residents counted in 2018's annual survey, down from a high of 969 in 2009.


== Economy ==

Fukuoka is the economic center of the Kyushu region, with an economy largely focused on the service sector. It is also the largest startup city in Japan, and is the only economic zone for startups. They have various services for startups like startup visa, tax reduction, and free business consultations. Fukuoka has the highest business-opening rate in Japan. Large companies headquartered in the city include Iwataya and Kyushu Electric Power. Fukuoka is also the home of many small firms playing a supportive role in the logistics, IT, and high-tech manufacturing sectors. Most of the region's heavy manufacturing takes place in the nearby city of Kitakyushu.
The GDP in Greater Fukuoka, Fukuoka Metropolitan Employment Area, was US$101.6 billion in 2010. Fukuoka is the primary economic center of the Fukuoka-Kitakyushu metropolitan area, which is the 4th largest economy in Japan. As of 2014, the area's PPP-adjusted GDP is estimated to be larger than those of metropolitan areas such as Melbourne, Kuala Lumpur, Lima, Vienna, Barcelona and Rome.Several regional broadcasters are based in the city, including Fukuoka Broadcasting Corporation, Kyushu Asahi Broadcasting, Love FM, RKB Mainichi Broadcasting, and Television Nishinippon Corporation.
The port of Hakata and Fukuoka Airport also make the city a key regional transportation hub. Fukuoka houses the headquarters of Kyushu Railway Company (JR Kyushu) and Nishi-Nippon Railroad. Air Next, a subsidiary of All Nippon Airways, is headquartered in Hakata-ku; prior to its dissolution, Harlequin Air was also headquartered in Hakata-ku.Fukuoka has its own stock exchange, founded in 1949. It is one of six in Japan.Fukuoka is one of the more affordable cities in Japan. Compared to New York City, rents are ~80% lower, restaurants are ~50% cheaper, and groceries are ~5% more expensive. 


== Culture ==
Fukuoka was selected as one of Newsweek's 10 "Most Dynamic Cities" in its July 2006 issue. It was chosen for its central Asian location, increasing tourism and trade, and a large increase in volume at its sea and airport. Fukuoka has a diverse culture and a wide range of cultural attractions.
In its July/August 2008 issue, Monocle selected Fukuoka as number 17 of the "Top 25 liveable cities". It was chosen for excellent shopping, outstanding food, good transport links, good museums, "a feeling of openness in its sea air", green spaces and because it is friendly, safe, clean and close to the rest of East Asia. The same survey in 2018 ranked Fukuoka at number 22.


=== Tourism ===

Fukuoka hosts more than 2 million foreign visitors annually, with the majority coming from neighboring South Korea, Taiwan and China. From the early 2010s Hakata became the beneficiary of significant growth in cruise ship tourism; particularly with visitors from China. After expansion and redevelopment of the Hakata Port international passenger ship terminal, the number of cruise ship port calls in 2016 is expected to exceed 400.Nearly ten thousand international students attend universities in or near the Fukuoka prefecture each year. Nearly 200 international conferences are held each year in Fukuoka.


==== Attractions ====

Sky Dream Fukuoka, in Fukuoka's western ward, was one of the world's largest Ferris wheels at a height of 120 meters. It was closed on September 2009. The surrounding shopping center, Marinoa City Fukuoka, still attracts millions of visitors each year. Other shopping centers that attract tourists include Canal City, JR Hakata City, and Hakata Riverain.Fukuoka Castle, located adjacent to Ohori Park in Maizuru Park, features the remaining stone walls and ramparts left after a devastating fire during the upheaval of the Meiji Restoration. It has now been preserved along with some reconstructed prefabricate concrete towers constructed during the 1950s and 1960s, when there was a trend across Japan to rebuild damaged castles as tourist attractions. Ōhori Park is also the location of one of Fukuoka City's major art galleries.
There are many temples with long histories including Tōchō-ji, Hakozaki Shrine, Kashii shrine, and Jōten-ji.
The Marine Park Uminonakamichi is located on a narrow cape on the northern side of the Bay of Hakata. The park has an amusement park, petting zoo, gardens, beaches, a hotel, and a large marine aquarium which opened in 1989.For tourists from other parts of Japan, local foods such as mentaiko, Hakata ramen and motsunabe are associated with Fukuoka. Yatai (street stalls) serving ramen can be found in Tenjin and Nakasu most evenings.
Fukuoka Tower is near the beach in Seaside Momochi, a development built for the 1989 Asia-Pacific Exhibition. The older symbol of the city, Hakata Port Tower is next to the international ferry terminal and is free to enter.
Itoshima, to the west of Fukuoka city, has recently become a very popular tourist destination.  There are many beaches along the coast, notably Futamigaura beach, where there is a famous Shinto shrine in the ocean, and Keya beach, which hosts the annual Sunset Live festival every September. Inland, there is the Shingon Buddhist temple called Raizan Sennyoji, where there are many Buddhist statues and stunning autumn foliage.The Buddhist Nanzoin temple is located in Sasaguri, just east of Fukuoka. It is claimed to be the largest statue of a reclining Buddha in the world.
There is a newly opened Kyushu National Museum in nearby Dazaifu.


=== Museums ===

Fukuoka Art Museum – In Ohori Park; contains a wide selection of contemporary and other art from around the world, including works by Mark Rothko, Roy Lichtenstein, and Salvador Dalí.
Fukuoka Asian Art Museum – contains art from various countries of Asia.
Fukuoka City Museum – displays a broad range of items from the region's history, including a spectacular gold seal.
Fukuoka Oriental Ceramics Museum
Fukuoka Prefectural Museum of Art
Genko Historical Museum (元寇史料館, Museum of the Mongol Invasion) – In Higashi Koen (East Park); displays Japanese and Mongolian arms and armor from the 13th century as well as paintings on historical subjects. Open on weekends.
Hakata Machiya Folk Museum – Dedicated to displaying the traditional ways of life, speech, and culture of the Fukuoka region.The Fukuoka Asian Culture Prize was established to honor the outstanding work of individuals or organizations in Asia.


=== Festivals ===

Fukuoka is home to many festivals (matsuri) that are held throughout the year. Of these, the most famous are Hakata Dontaku and Hakata Gion Yamakasa.


==== Yamakasa ====
Yamakasa (山笠), held for two weeks each July, is Fukuoka's oldest festival with a history of over 700 years. The festival dates back to 1241 when a priest called Shioichu Kokushi saved Hakata from a terrible plague by being carried around the city on a movable shrine and throwing water. Teams of men (no women, except small girls, are allowed), representing different districts in the city, commemorate the priest's route by racing against the clock around a set course carrying on their shoulders floats weighing several thousand pounds. Participants all wear shimekomi (called fundoshi in other parts of Japan), which are traditional loincloths.
Each day of the two-week festival is marked by special events and practice runs, culminating in the official race that takes place the last morning before dawn. Tens of thousands line the streets to cheer on the teams. During the festival, men can be seen walking around many parts of Fukuoka in long happi coats bearing the distinctive mark of their team affiliation and traditional geta sandals. The costumes are worn with pride and are considered appropriate wear for even formal occasions, such as weddings and cocktail parties, during the festival.

		


==== Hakata Dontaku ====
Hakata Dontaku (博多どんたく) is held in Fukuoka City on May 3 and 4. Boasting over 800 years of history, Dontaku is attended by more than 2 million people, making it the festival with the highest attendance during Japan's Golden Week holidays. During the festival, stages are erected throughout downtown for traditional performances and a parade of floats is held. The full name is Hakata Dontaku Minato Matsuri.The festival was stopped for seven years during the Meiji era. Since it was restarted in the 12th year of the Meiji era it has been known as Hakata Dontaku.


=== Music ===
Notable musical names in J-pop include Ayumi Hamasaki (allegedly Japan's richest woman), singer-songwriter Ringo Shiina, hugely popular singer-songwriter duo Chage & Aska, singer-songwriter Eri Nobuchika, Misia, Masamune Kusano and Yui. During the 1970s, local musicians prided themselves on their origins and dubbed their sound, Mentai Rock.
Morning Musume 6th generation member Reina Tanaka was also born here in 1989 along with 9th generation member Erina Ikuta in 1997.
Dominican songwriter and singer Juan Luis Guerra pays homage to the city in his bachata song Bachata en Fukuoka (2010).
HKT 48 have their own Theater at Nishitetsu Hall.


== Transport ==

Fukuoka is served by Fukuoka Airport, the San'yō Shinkansen and the Kyushu Shinkansen high-speed rail line and other JR Kyushu trains at Hakata Station and by ferry. JR Kyushu and a Korean company operate hydrofoil ferries (named Beetle and Kobee) between Hakata and Busan, South Korea. The city has three subway lines: the Kūkō Line, the Hakozaki Line, and the newest one, Subway Nanakuma Line, opened on February 2, 2005. A private railway line, run by Nishitetsu is also heavily used and connects the downtown area of Tenjin to the city of Ōmuta.


== Sports ==

Fukuoka is the home of the Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks, one of Japan's top professional baseball teams. Threatened with bankruptcy and forced by its creditors to restructure, former owner Daiei sold the Hawks to Softbank Capital in 2004.
Fukuoka is home to a professional football team, Avispa Fukuoka.
Annual sporting events include:

The All Japan Judo Category Championships are held in early April.
The Kyushu ekiden, beginning in Nagasaki and ending in Fukuoka, the world's longest relay race, held in October. (Defunct)
The November tournament of professional Sumo is held at the Fukuoka Kokusai Center.
Fukuoka International Open Marathon Championships, with start/finish at Heiwadai Athletic Stadium, held on the 1st Sunday of December.Fukuoka has hosted the following sporting events:

1983 Asian Volleyball Championship for Women
1995 Summer Universiade
1997 Pan Pacific Swimming Championships
1998 Women's Volleyball World Championship
1999 Asian Basketball Championship
2001 World Aquatics Championships.
2006 IAAF World Cross Country Championships.
Fukuoka International Women's Judo Championships from 1983 to 2006.
2013-14 Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final

== International relations ==
Fukuoka has nine sister cities.
The city established the Asian Pacific City Summit in 1994. It consists of 26 Asia-Pacific cities.

The tower's light changes to different colors. Tourists get discount when they present their passports. The view deck offers a great view of Fukuoka at night. I bet it's also great to visit during daytime in order to see the water and mountains surrounding the place. There is
This is a cool respite on a very hot July day with fine views all over Fukuoka. Information on the center wall is helpful and viewing machines are available.
Look well, look twice! An interesting study of lines and cubes. Look at the illusion of the mirrored tower. Looks like four standing rectangles.
great sights to see on top, night time views is great the attendants all can speak english and very lovely lots of chinese tourists

Fukuoka Tower is a 234m tall tower located in the bay-side Momochihama area of Fukuoka and is the tallest seaside tower in Japan. The main observation deck is 123m above the ground and there is a a café/lounge on the deck below this. The tower affords really great views of both

I visited the tower during the star festival hoping to get a glimpse of the 5 minute illumination supposedly scheduled and was disappointed as it did not start on time, nor was there any indication of when it will begin. The food and ambience was great though! There were many

This is a wonderful experience in Fukuoka and you should visit if you are there nearby. As this tower is located near to the sea, you can enjoy the view of the city on one side and sea on the other side. There is a restaurant on the top floor. If you visit to this place near to

While staying in Hilton Sea Hawk hotel, we had a good view of the Fukuoka Tower from our room window. The tower is 123 metres high with a panoramic view of the city. There are many shops at the ground floor. The view from the top deck is excellent.

Not only is the Fukuoka Tower an icon of Fukuoka, it is also one nice site to visit. It is located near the beach where some shops are located. A walk in this tranquil spot is nice if the weather is not so hot as when we visited.
We went on this as part of a tour and it was a good way to get an overall view of Fukuoka. You travel up a lift so easy access. There is also a small shopping mall with tourist things and coffee.
Amazing site. Situated near the sea shor. View is very breath taking. Amazing sight seeing. Lift goes up swiftly. Children will love to see sky view of the city.

It looked like a building but was a bit surprised to find out that it's merely a tower. There's a small restaurant above and you can have a good view of the city and the bay. There's nothing much in the area as well. Nice if you like views from above but it's not that high. A

Went this afternoon and so wanted to see the sights from the top of the tower but have a thing for heights... but I went on. Seeing a bunch of kids playing and the kind hostesses made it easier and did snap a couple photos but was happy to get down to terra firma. Definite stop

Ok, it's a high tower, has a mascot playing with kids, and nice scenery up there. So you could take your kids and spend 1 or 2 hour here. However, if you are not travel with kids there s nothing much up there unless you want to kill your time. Hence one visit per lifetime is

The place has a souvenir shop and convenience store. It is nearby the beach (only 1 minute walk away, sells ice cream and other treats) and is near other places of interest ie. Fukuoka library, Fukuoka City Museum. There is a cafe in the compound, and offers a photo taking
We were impressed with the efficiency of the service staff. So immaculately dressed even with gloves The view is spectacular but there's nothing else offered up there.
Went up the tower, had a good view over the city of Fukuoka. Easy accessible by public bus. English is dpiken, everyone us very helpful. Signs are all in Japaneese.

From marinoa you may ask the information about the bus going to fukuoka tower. This are the things you may do altogother- meinohama-marinoa outlet store- nokoshima-fukuoka tower-momochi (behind fukuoka tower) all by the bus nishitetsu.
Good place to see 360 degree view of the city. Please add more activities upstairs, it will be boring to stay for more than 1 hr.

Typical of any elevated city observatory affording great views of the city, beaches, mountains, and water. We headed over after a baseball game at the nearby Fukuoka Yafuoka Dome. Though I enjoyed the visit I don't think its worth going out of your way to see it. The structure
This is one of the "touristy" spots in Fukuoka. It's nice to go up there to see the city and take pictures. It only takes about an hour to do the tour.

It was easy getting here by bus. Not much around or in Fukuoka Tower. It's $15 to go up for a nice view of the city, but seriously that doesn't take more than 30 minutes. Maybe if they added things to do around the area it would be more worth the trip. I would not go again.

We visited Fukuoka tower on our way walking to Atago shrine. It was work checking out if you like to see city views. I have been up Tokyo sky tree and I'll be fair and say it was a similar experience in terms of the view, however Fukuoka tower is a lot cheaper and there was no
It's still a little long way from the subway station and needs 20 minutes walk. Nishitetsu bus is the best choice.

Fukuoka tower is less expensive than the tokyo tower or sky tree! and it offers a 20% discount for foreigners. the architecture is quite interesting because of its triangular shape and it is much much smaller than it looks. one side features the beach and seaside, while the
Far from everything. Very expensive. A huge waste of time. You can go to the Hilton hotel next door. Top floor and have a coke and enjoy the view for less. Just a rip off.
Big tower which I've ever seen. Walk so far from subway station. You must pay for go up to tower. In front of tower is the beach, you can walk along with the beach and nice place around there.

I was a representative of the Hawaiian state pavilion at the 1989 Asia Pacific expo held in Fukuoka called Yokatopia. The theme structure built for the fair was this tower. So nice to return and see it still standing as a lovely reminder of that fantastic time. I loved living

We were a bit disappointed as there's not much to do at this tower except get a view of Fukuoka from high up. There's another level 3 floors down which is supposed to be for couples. Other than viewing the city, there's nothing else except for some shops selling souvenirs on
The Fukuoka Tower is nothing really special, just a telecommunication skyscraper. I read somewhere that this location was used for a KingKong movie, so I had to see it:) It made a nice photo-op:)
so snowy day i visited here. windy also. this tower is northern part of fukuoka. good place even not so high. not so special but good place for windy day. i visited fukuoka city musium also

Nice view of the city. Lookout for a huge "Camera" near the entrance. You can place your camera on it for a nice selfie with the tower as the background. Remember to get your free ticket if your birthday falls within 3 days of your visit.

Standing tall at 234meters from the base to tip, this tower is usually visited by tourists. Only if you are interested to see the entire city from its tallest peak. Fukuoka tower is often referred to as the "Mirror sail" -- made with 8,000 one way mirrors the triangle tower is
The weather was rainy but there were still some pretty good views. I love going to high places so this was a good trip.
if you hate china tourist, you must avoid this building because there's so many china group tour, very loud and dirty.
Choose a clear day if possible for the superb panoramic views of the city. Allow minimum of two hours to maximise the visit.

The area around it is beautiful, with the sea, the dome and many restaurants and cafés, but in winter it was a bit empty. The tower is just a tall building to enjoy the view of the bay, but to be honest it didn't seem to be worth the ticket.
You get a great view of the ocean - worth going to if you haven't been up a sky tower yet. Try to go on a clear sunny day
We were there for Christmas and the tower looked amazing. It was great to be there before, during, and after sunset. Great views. Definitely a must!
Fukuoka tower character welcome at the entrance. There is no big deal, except to see the scenery in high places.
800 yen per head to go up the tower and the view is no better than agato shrine. The general area of Fukuoka tower is soulless.

It takes me around 20 minutes walk from Fujisaki Sation on the Fukuoka City Subway Kuko Line (K04) to the tower, I was attracted by Fukuoka Art Museum and the Unviersity on the way. In this neighborhood, it is better to walk in a relaxed way.

I have planned to visit this place after leaving Ohori Park as it is locates a few station away from the park (Nishijin Subway Station). From the station, you have to walk around 20 mins. The view is great during the night but please make sure that you have checked the weather
... Spectacular views of the City. Perhaps, like no other ... Well, actually, you can get a similar view at the Hilton Seahawks Hotel top floor -- for free.

Went up with a 20% discount, it was on the map I got from the hostel. The view is beautiful, you can even see mountains! And I discovered the beach while up here, which I later visited too. Don't forget to walk down to level 3 and catch an elevator down from there. And try out

A great way to get a bird-eye view of the city. The view is beautiful. During the night, the building lights up according to the season. I was there during the winter, and the building had a Christmas tree shaped light up on its building. Its was really cool.

As we found Fukuoka in general to be quite grey looking, going to the Fukuoka Tower was a welcome change. It is set in quite a nice beach location and is great to look at. We took the lift to the top, had drinks and snacks and watched the sun go down. The views are lovely and it
The sharming of the Fukuoka tower dues to its location close to the beach. Therefore the tower offers the sea view and the city view. The main desk is relative small so that nothing else to do.

I went with my husband, and felt the staff so kind. Going up to the top by the elevator and take a break in the coffee shop. You could have a cake and a drink here. The night view you can see for a few hundred miles.

The staff at the counter are very friendly. My daughter wanted to have a photo taken with one of the staff manning the elevator and she is obliged. The view at the top is great specially at sunset. It was raining when we were there but the view is still great. You can also put a

I went by myself, and found the staff so kind. The woman at the main desk, the women in the elevators who gave their information in Japanese then in English for me, the lone westerner. The view is pretty hard to beat. I went on a sunny day and you could see for miles in all
We went there on sunset. Cost is about 800 yen. Great view from the top. Very nice city on the coast There is a restaurant there but we did not try it
Nothing special really... I gave 3 stars just because it is next to the beach where you can go after... There are other good spots to see Fukuoka panorama and for free!...

What better view can you see for a few hundred yen. Take the elevator to the top during the day and you might get to watch a wedding in progress across the waterway on the private island. Take you time and enjoy some pix with your friends and family.
Great night view from fukuoka tower. It is just in front of momochi beach! I Loved fresh air there.
Definitely nice place to visit if you dont suffer height....scary the view but amazing to see all city from above in a circular way..
Nice tall iconic tower of Fukuoka, located near Momochi Seaside Park. Can go up its observation decks for beautiful views of city and sea!

Fukuoka Tower is a famous landmark of the city. Its exterior modern architectural design and glass structure give towering majestic feel, even though it is really not high. For breathtaking 360 degree view of the city, a visit to the top of the tower is a must.
It's literally the highest point in the city with a restaurant on top. There's also a 7-11 at the base of the tower and it's near the board walk. You can't visit Fukuoka without coming here.

The Fukuoka Tower is not as tall as those in Shanghai, but it is still a worthwhile visit to see this beautifully designed glass structure. From the outside, the architecture is very modern with clean lines and lots of glass in it's design. From the top, there are impressive

During our trip, the weather was so nice so we wanted to have a nice view of the city. The view is nice but we were a bit disappointed as the tower is not that high. But if you have nothing to do for 20 min, you can go up !

Tower has been gone, only if this was in the movies, LOL :), I guess, and the story goes on as the whole city was destroyed, OMG!!! Fukuoka Tower is here and still provides all around look at this charming and beautiful city with the mountains on one side and the cove, I took

Walk to the Momochi district and take in the side streets, views of the tower from the distance along the way. Enjoy 360 degree views of Fukuoka City, the harbor and surrounding mountains. The tower is about 230m high, one of the tallest seaside towers in Japan and is serviced
i recommend everyone visit fukuoka city to go to see fukuoka tower i was with my girlfriend and very enjoy and i want go again
It is kind of out of the way from the center of the city. Not sure it was worth the special trip
If the weather is good you will have a great view. Price is cheap (compared to the TV tower in Auckland)
The view of the city and the water is great, but it is expensive for the family to go up the tower..

Great to get a nice overview of the city, and the pointers to other countries (e.g. England!!) is a nice touch. Remember to brandish your passport to get a discount as an "alien" - the locals have to pay full price.

This is a lovely (yet ordinary) tower, located by the sea. While the view from the tower is nice, you don't really have to go up the tower - just go to the nearby Hilton hotel and get the exact same views. Having said that, the tower does look beautiful at night, when it is
Another tower, another view. Fukuoka doesn't have the best view ever but you know it's still fun to be s high above the seashore. This is not Tokyo sky tree so not a lot of co-visitors.

it was ok for us but it is not one of the best thing we did at fukuoka. The area when we walk to the tower are nice and peaceful. We love that moment. but the top of the tower are same like everywhere else in the world.
Weather was good so we had a very clear view from the top. The lighting at the 3rd level for lovers sanctuary was poor so photos don't turn out well.

If coming to this area, be sure to see the dome and stop by robosquare (shop dedicated to robots) in the TNC mall next door. Truthfully you'll get as good of a view of the city by simply going into the Hilton a few blocks down and getting a drink at their 35th floor bar. But
As you might expect it has an incredible views over the whole area. Definitely worth the trip if in the area.

Fukuoka Tower is a fair distance from the downtown core, without too much else around. It provides a great vantage point to overlook the city and harbour. We were there on a bit of a dull, grey day. Perhaps our assessment would be different if we visited on a sunny day.

If you go to Fukuoka, you must go to Fukuoka tower!! You can see the amazing view there, so beautiful:) And also Fukuoka Tower looks wonderful:) I went here at night, I could see the beautiful Fukuoka scenery!!!!!! Very clean, kind, nice. They have a restaurant and a cafe, so
The are next to the tower is an attraction in itself, with plenty of seafood restaurants and a nice pier. The tower itself is very beautiful. The view is amazing and the admission is quite cheap.
not the have-to viewed.i think there aren't something interest. may be it's too old.but their stories are wonderful.

Nice view from the top of tower. We can view the fukuoka city from the. tower. Altough not to many stall sell the souvenir. We can enjoy the sunset from the tower and can walk away sourround there. Souvenir shop in ground floor are limited.

Due to the Civil Aviation Regulation, there's no higher building than this tower from the airport. Up on the tower, the city and the bay view can be seen. The tower has a western restaurant on the ground level and the gift shop. The nearest city subway station is Nishijin, and

I like views from high place. I've been to many different towers around the world. I had time in Fukuoka, I didn't want to miss the opportunity to go up to the observation deck. Ticket is 800 yen but if you show your non-Japanese passport, it is 640 yen. I didn't know that at

If you like skylines and view from the top, you would like this one. A panoramic view around showing the city and the water. There was a discount for tourists and paid about 1300 yen for 2 people. The elevator ride to the top was pretty cool but kinda gave me a headache. Once we

I visited the Fukuoka tower last September 22. Fukuoka tower is basically a structure with a viewing deck located 123 meters from the ground. Snack bars and souvenir shops are found at the ground floor. We paid an admission fee of 800 yen but we were given a 20% discount (perks
There isn't much you can say about this place except it had great views. If you're into that, then I'd recommend going
If you are a night view lover, you would love the view commanding all the hakata.
A long busride from the center, but absolutely worthwile. The building itself is very pretty at night. Like a giant x-mas tree. The view is beautiful, Hakata is a large and beautiful city.
You can get a nice view of Fukuoka on the observation deck if you go a sunny day. Worth a visit if you are around that area.
Get a good view of Fukuoka, and get a lock to put on the observation deck. Great views of the city, mountains, and sunset
Went there in the evening, the atmosphere was brilliant! You can go picnic there on weekends, very lively!

It is a long walk from the subway station. If you have to go there, better take the bus. There is a bus terminal just next to JR hakata. The Robo square is just next to the tower. We didn't have much time to explore this area. I saw there may be something else (like a disaster

Gives you a good big picture of Fukuoka. Good panoramic views. Even tells you are 540 kms to Korea. So might reconsider yr decision to swim there. :) Would also be good if u have someone along they knows the rasa to give u done historical perspective plus to also see the current
So many towers in Japan - this one is as good as any other. Nice views of the city & harbour, you can get a great perspective and orientation of Fukuoka. Reasonably priced.

A good stop for visitors to understand the layout of the city. The tower is about 230 meters high, apparently the tallest seaside tower in entire Japan. You can enjoy a 360 degrees view of the city and the Hakata Bay from 2 different observation decks and a sky lounge. Entry
We saw Fukuoka's city lights as we went at 8:00 pm. Beautiful! Not crowded too. Only downside was that most of the souvenir shops were closed by then and only 7-11 was open.

Fantastic views of Fukuoka at a very reasonable price. As an international guest we only paid about $6 for the trip 240 mts up. Also had lunch at the top of the tower. Also a good price for pizza, pasta or Japanese

Worth visiting a landmark symbol that represents Fukuoka. They offered a foreigner discount when asked. There is a cafe 1 floor down from top level- it was nice to sit and enjoy a snack with the view of the city.

This tower is high and you can see almost the whole of Fukuoka City. Located next to the Hospital where my son was born, it really brings back memories. We made our wish on the top floor where there is a star that grants wish. Check it out.
Panoramic view of Fukuoka City. Bring along a video-camera to take the nearby scenery. Travel agency arranged to bring us here.

If you have seen Tokyo tower, Kyoto Tower than you will feel one more tower but its bit different as it has its own beauty. The best things its next to sea and worth having a nice small walk with your wife and kids ...Good Luck
Fun to see the city from here - it is worth taking a trip to the top. The fee is reasonable. This of course is if you aren't afraid of heights!

Fukuoka tower offers the basic city view that most major cities do. The tower is located right on the beach and there are signs that point out spots of interest and directions to other cities of the world which is pretty interesting. The tower is in a good location, with nearby
You can enjoy seaside view and mountain view. It is located a little bit far from central city you can access by bus. There are several good restaurant around the tower you can enjoy food as well.

Great view. Try visiting it just before nightfall, to see a morning and night view of Fukuoka. The 5th level viewing deck is around 120+ meters high, with a view all around. It's quite romantic by the evening - they even capitalize on this by having a "lover's floor" on the 3rd
here you can ride the high speed elevator reaching up to 123 meters. On top can see the sea view and city view of Fukuoka. Pretty good view for tourists.

Nice views to see the whole of Fukuoka bay area. I also liked how foreigners get a discount on entry! Wow, great! Also, the guides spoke whatever language of the people in the elevator car. This included Korean, English, Chinese, etc.

I been with a friend to visit Fukuoka sea side .Very nice place , there is Hilton Hotel and Google House and many terassa on the beach , opening eaven in february . Any way in the final we been in Fukuoka Tower on 123 m high with a speed elevetor and a nice girl guide . Ticket

If you've ever been to any kind of viewing platform or tall building with observation deck, you know what to expect. You can see all different parts of Fukuoka, plus explanations. Combine it with a trip to Yahoo Dome, the musuem or outlet malls at Marinoa.

Spectacular view from a very high tower. This tour runs smoothly, there is a usual line up expecially various groups at the entrance. Lovely clad ladies invite a smooth ride up to the tower where one sees a panoramic view of the city. The space up top is narrow, there are a few
Unless you're already in the area, skip it. It is cool to look up from the ground floor, tho, since the building is hollow.

Not a must but actually nice, the Fukuoka tower provides the visitors with unmatched views of Fukuoka city. However, the city is huge you'll be still able to see only a small part of it (half of the view is see).

After visiting both Tokyo and Seoul tower, I suppose you've seen one tower you've seen them all. But Fukuoka tower has some nice views of the beach, friendly staff and is reasonably priced. Worth half an hour if you've got some time :)

The view is nice, but the whole place including the viewing deck is a bit kitsch. It's hard to get to on public transportation and is quite pricey for what it is. Save your money and do something else in Fukouoka!

The area around the tower is nice and the beach park there is vibrant. The beach has a few restaurants and cafes which is perfect for a drink. There is no real reason to go up in the tower as you can get better views from the Nishi Park or the ACROS building in Tenjin.
It is very good place to overview Fukuoka. Foreign tourists have discount for entry tickets.

Fukuoka tower is 123 mt. high, and it was builded with the solely purpose of sightseen. The view is great, with the beachs of Momochi and the Hilton Hotel views. Its open to at least 9:00 pm, so you can catch sunset and nigth skyline. Discounts for foreigners with passport.

Compare to any viewing towers in Tokyo or Osaka Fukuoka Tower is just average with not many thing to do other than starring at the bay and part of city, looking at lovers' locks and perhaps a cup of pricy coffee at the lower floor. On the way to the tower though, drop in

Definitely worth a visit, the views are gorgeous but skip the restaurant, we sat down and stood up again after reading the average offering of takeaway style, suspiciously microwaved-looking pasta dishes.

We went up the Fukuoka Tower while on a self-tour of southern Japan. It happened to be my partner's 40th birthday while we were in Fukuoka and what I read in my guide book is true, that you get complimentary entry to the tower if you provide evidence that it is your birthday on

My wife and I wanted to check out the view from the observation deck of the city's tallest building. It was incredible. Views of the city, mountains, and water. There are more than a dozen restaurants in the building, serving mostly Japanese food...but couple places featured

A great tower to observe Fukuoka and its surrounding islands. There are plenty of information boards in English and the observation decks give an awesome 360 view of the area. Try and go on a clear sky day

Quite expensive for what you get. Views are nothing special. We ate in the cafe, but the food was pretty average. You are much better off eating on the boardwalk by the beach. Do visit Robot World next door though - that is fun.
Service is great, lift is speedy. The area nearby is picturesque. Always bring my relatives to see this tower.

google:
Visiting a skyscraper in isn't usually the top thing to do when travelling in Japan... but this place can easily be a highlight of your Fukuoka trip. 💯

Observation deck displays some amazing views of the city and the beach. Try & get a good photographer by your side if you're planning to go up 🔝
nice place to see the whole bay view! it's quite easy to go to by city bus.

Has a nice view. But one annoying thing was that they take a photo of you, which they will not give to you unless you pay. So basically when you come down from the observation tower, they will have printed the photo and ask 20$ for it. If you don't pay they just throw it away
There's a small charge to go up the tower. It's worth it. The view from the top is magnificent. The Tower Love Light is a great photo op addition.

a must-to-visit place in Fukuoka. This is the tallest building in Fukuoka city. In order to goo up to the building you need to pay extra cash, but if you only enjoying the building from outside it's free. You can find many store near the building and behind of it, there's a beautiful beach.

I loved the views of Fukuoka. The viewing deck has maps posted around so you know what buildings you’re seeing. The illuminations at night are amazing. The only thing I wish was different is the paid parking located around the building. Admission is fairly cheap as well, which was nice.

Beautiful tower and the surrounding area. Arrived very early in the morning but did not go up. There's convenience stores, cafes and restaurants nearby. Heard that the night view would have been better. Momochi seaside park is just opposite of the tower and nearby. Would recommend to go at night. Can be very crowded with tourists.

Excellent views of the beach, mountains, and Fukuoka city. If you take only the train, it’s a long but nice walk from the closest station. You can get good shots of the tower. Fastest way is by taking the bus and you’re dropped off one …

For people who love peace and quiet in their travels, it has a serene atmosphere and beautiful view at the top. And it has cafe and dining place with great views also.
You can take nice pictures here. There is also a really cool beach behind it
Reasonable tickets price for the awesome view, problem is that u can’t get here by train, but bus is pretty easy accessible.
Nice view outside. There are 3 floors in the top of tower for panoramic view. But it costs 800 yen. I think it's expensive for this place

1084/10049 would come again. Not because its bad but because its a once in a lifetime experience. Though, it is of course not that beautiful, but still cheap and you get a free small photo! For a few hundred yen you will get a big photo. Cheap cheap cheap big worth.
Loved it.  It is a must visit place if you are passing through Fukuoka.  I would suggest going around sunset.  Just beautiful views and a great oversight of the city.

It‘s pretty much capitalism deluxe, but what are you supposed to do with a tower anyway? You can pay for a picture, …

I already liked the outside view, because it was illuminated in a halloween theme. After I went to the top for 800 ¥ I had a view which was even as amazing.
