Fun place to spend an evening, particularly with kids. There's a Saboten for tonkatsu, ice cream, and generally lots of things to see and do.

This place is a little disjointed but has a lot of nice shops and is a bit of a break from all the huge department stores and is bit more like a mall. Ramen stadium on one of the upper floors is well worth a visit too.
Hakata and Tenjin area generally has a wide range of shopping options. This mall is a good stop for shoppers.
Nice shopping mall where I only bought a crep. It was delicious. But otherwise there is a lot of stores like in Tenjin but I actually liked Canal city better than Tenjin.

Not far from jr hakata station and subway station or even walk from jr hakata city. Can take the bus from jr hakata too. Have plenty of shops ,restaurants: moomin cafe, daiso , theatre., etc . you can enjoy and relax in here all day long. At night there are the special lighting
The mall is big but too big, shops are not well organised. Not much shop provide discount. It is good to go there if you have some target shops here. But I will recommend Tenjin more.

Another neat and clean shopping area, nothing extravaganza but enjoyable nonetheless. Go outside. walk along the river and get into that Japanese traditional shopping strip, undercover and your exercise done for the day.

Nice shopping mall with varieties. H&M, Uniqulo, MUJI, Gap, to name a few. There is ramen stadium which inside the area there are a number of Japanese ramen shop. We tried one and it's good. Besides the ramen stadium, there is also Ichiran (famous ramen shop) in other parts

Seems to be over-rated. Yes, plenty of shops and a thousand over restaurants?? Seems to be your typical mall. The water canal in the mall was closed for renovations!! Grrr... a third for us in our trip! There are lots of shops, so do cater for a whole day if you want to
Although impressive from afar and well located inside the centre of town; when you get up close its hard to get excited about generic, international shopping chains.

This is an attraction described in a local leaflet for visitors. We took the 100 yen bus (circular route) near Tenjin station to this large mall. The routes in the complex are rather complicated and you definitely need a map to find your way to certain shop. A few levels in

Canal city is essentially just a big shopping mall. But there are little treasures hidden within. A little market running down one side where trinkets were being sold. A beautiful open floor with clothing, homewares and a comfortable reading area. And on the very top of it all
The redeeming feature of this otherwise totally generic place was the "ramen stadium" where a number of intriguing ships were selling tickets for their particular ramen treats. This was fun!

The mall has a lot of popular brand stores such as H&M, Bershka and Zara. They also have some of the same stores that you'd find in malls such as HEP 105 in Osaka and Shibuya 109 in Tokyo, which caters to younger/trendy. The theater on top does have English movies, but they're a

This station is quite busy and lots of shops and restaurants with varieties. It also have big department stores. It's really a shopping heaven can spend whole day there. One thing good is we got the tax refund right away if we purchased more than 5000 yen. Make sure you check

I am from the Philippines which I consider the mall capital of the world. Some of the largest malls in the world are located the Philippines like Greenbelt, SM Megamall, Mall of Asia, etc. I also been to some of the best and largest malls in the world like the Mall of the

It's quite a big place with a canal spanning through several buildings. Architecturally it might be more interesting but it gets a bit cumbersome for those of us with strollers. Several shops on one floor and off we go to locate the lift again. Did spend a long time at Uniqlo
Surprisingly good food to choose from and plenty of shops to look around. Just beside the Grand Hyatt and very convenient.
There are lots of different shops in canal city. Make sure to get a floor guide as soon as you get there so you can already plot where to go.

It is basically a mall, the only interesting part is that it has a small canal right inside. Shopping wise has all luxury brands and a few Japanese ones too. The size is huge but you can find English maps for the mall easily
The mall was very confusing. What attracted us to the place was the pictures on the Internet, but the place was quite disappointing, not very similar to the picture.
Comfortable shopping center, modern and surrounded internally by nice areas. It has a lot of internation brands' shops and you can do a lot of activities there. Recommended for hot days.

Chance to revisit but only visited the bottom level near the fountains. Good shopping with some small shops with good prices for kids goods, lollies and home wares. Summer sales were on as well as a summer show that closed off a significant part of the fountain area. Some wet

This is a really big shopping centre that has lots and lots of shops. The building is showing its age but is still well maintained. Shops are pretty much the same everywhere. They do have some nice restaurants that I didn't see elsewhere though. And there is a Ramen Stadium

It was rain season when I went here, so going thru the various shops, eateries, etc. while it rained outside was a good way to spend the day. The fourth floor had great Japanese cuisine to try. Got a few cute items to bring back to the States. Even had movie theater inside.
There are a lot of local stores and restaurants to explore. This is definitely not over crowded with tourists, and a good place to get a feel for the real deal.
Nice place and we all enjoyed. Good Japanese and European and American brands. Also surrounded by nice restaurants. Good for a rainy day
Nothing great. Usual shopping experience with variety of shops. Go only when you have time to spare. Over rated and over hyped.
Visited for the poorly named ramen stadium and found a mall with a food court nothing wrong but nothing very special. There is an extensive arcade so probably good for families.
City under city. A must watch thing. You can't imagine where r u. Every thing is there you wish for. Food courts are in numbers. But not for vegetarian people.

Passed through Canal City while walking from our hotel near Hakata Station to Tenjin. It's just a typical huge mall with all the ubiquitous brands you see elsewhere plus some local brands. Nice water feature but really didn't stay long enough to see the fountain show, if there

Canal City celebrates its 20th anniversary this year so for a mall that old it seems a little bit dated and even faded in some areas. Still it's a pleasant place to shop, with so many types of stores under one roof, and a cinema too. Don't miss Ramen Stadium and the newer annex
Usual brands and shops are located at this place such as H&M, Uniqlo etc... There are also some restaurants. We tried Tempura that was very yummy.

This gigantic muti-buildings complex has almost everything a traveller needs. Ramen, sushi, bbq, a la carte, western food, shopping (jillion shops), game centre, ice cream parlour, hotel. Also very close to Hakata station about 10 minute walk.

Variety of high end shops and stalls to choose from. The mall is huge so a little challenging when you navigate the first time. But there are maps for your reference and the concierge can speak English.
A fairly confusing shopping mall with an architecture which reminds one of Las Vegas. Not exactly fascinating...
It is a bog standard shopping mall with some interesting water features, restaurants & a cinema. It doesn't differ from most shopping malls you'd find dotted around Japanese big cities.

This was a very large mall. It was nice browsing the shops although it was mostly foreign brands (H&M, Zara, etc). There are a lot of interesting restaurants (I recommend checking out Moomin Cafe&Bakery) and the Ramen Stadium (on the 6th floor) is also worth visiting as it

Shopping is always part of the itinerary when you go to Fukuoka. This is their main shopping mall. Brands abound and you can get good prices if there's a sale. This is also where the ramen stadium is.

Perhaps it was the time of day but this was disappointing. A collection of ugly buildings housing shops and eateries. It seemed to be lacking atmosphere and certainly pales in comparison to Tenjin as a shopping centre.
Now a days shoppers centers all look similar. This one is no exception. You can find all the major brands here. Lay-out might be a bit confusing though.

Canal city is obviously a very happening place and was an j retesting side of Japan to see. We stopped off in the moomin cafe and gift shop as my family are moomin mad, prices were steep but in a cutesy place like this that is to be expected. You automatically got a giant
Just another mall. Expected more wowzers canals. It's just some water... Makes it rather inconvenient to get around to shops.

This mall has many local and international brands. On the top floor, there is Ramen Stadium, which offers various sorts of ramen noodles. Also, towards the center of the mall, there's a water fountain show, similar to Macau Wynn's and Las Vegas Bellagio. This mall is

It takes less 20 minutes walk from Tenji Station or Hakata Station. And it's more convenient to go by bus. Many foreigners are shopping there especially Korean and Chinese. Shops,cafes,restaurants,theater,cinemas and also hotels are located in the Canal City Hakata. A nice place

The mall houses many local and international brand names. It also has the Ramen Stadium which was a dining experience for us - "shopping" for ramen of our liking. If you're not a ramen fan, there are still many other options. We visited this mall mainly for its Ramen
Big outdoor shops, very crowded and noisy but fun to walk around and try different kind of foods. All kind of stores are available in this area, just not enough energy to cover all in one visit.

Great shopping mall for every shoppers! All Fashion stores, kids and teens shops, Souvenir shops and Dining paradise! H&M, Uniqlo, Muji, Beam, Onitsuka Tiger, Gap, Jump shops, JIN, Matsumoto Kiyoshi, Starbucks, Dipper Dan, Moomin Restuarant, Ramen Shops, Game Center, Movies

When Fukuoka is your first stop, this mall will probably impress you. It has literally everything from restaurants to clothing stores and from game arcades to a movie theatre. It's nice to stroll around on a rainy day and the architecture isn't bad. It also has a nice fountain
It was big. You'll find Disney store there and the big Uniqlo store. You see other known brands here. We weren't able to go around that much though

typical japanese mall full of japanese brands and foreign brands of product the center part of the mall has a canal like attraction and we were able to watch some mall shows given it was a sunday restaurants are abundant on the top floor which also serves as a outlook on hakata

I came for ABC Mart. It was a 15 mins walk from hakata station, and I discover another nice shopping paradise for those who are keen to buy international brands and also some Japanese local goods. The shopping mall is a bit dark inside and a bit of renovation. There seems to be

I think the only real problem you'll have shopping in Fukuoka is deciding how much time you have to shop, as the variety of stores is great. We spent a few hours at Canal city wandering and buying a few things here and there once we became orientated with the layout. I would
Walked the canal area and sampled the food and window shop the stores while enjoying the sun and soaking up the culture Love the city

I stayed Hyatt hotel which was located within canal city. Canal city is an amazing place You get all the things you need for a traveller and more. I bought some souvenirs and also ate the best Ramen I ever tried in the 5 floor.
This is a huge mall spread out over 4 buildings. The shops are all designer and restaurants were pricey and looked average.

Many shops including famous brands like Gap, H&M and Uniglo. Beef Taigen restaurant and Ichiran Ramen is conveniently located there too. Cinemas with 4D effects was great when we watched the launch of Star Wars 7 there.

This place has it all. Great location in downtown Fukuoka, beautiful view of the canal, and loads of shops and places to eat. The crapes shop on the ground floor is amazing, they have a ramen "stadium" with a bunch of different ramen shops, there is also a movie theater, and

Huge mall split into a few blocks. Many variety of shops and eateries to suit all taste and budgets. Ramen Stadium, with about 10 different types of ramen shops/stalls, is at the 5th storey and there is a nice stretch of open waterway in the middle with a lovely musical fountain

Yes, it's very colorful and structurally "interesting". But in all of Fukuoka, Hakata & Tenjin included, the best tax-free shopping was here! Don't know how long it will last though. Ask information for "tourist-friendly" stores and eateries, like H&M and Dipper Dan:))) The
Several type of shop. Atmosphere is great. Espicially MUJI for MUJI's fan. Food is great and have several types.

The mall has everything, famous brand store, canal within the outside of mall, with fountain show, many restaurants, movie theater, Oh yes, there is also the Ramen stadium on the fifth floor. Great shopping, musical fountain show, great taste of Hakata Ramen, what more can you

We really didn't expect much when we visited the mall, but given that it's the biggest mall in Fukuoka, it definitely has its own attraction and we did shop a lot! If you are a show lovers, you should know that buying shoes from ABC Mart in Japan is very reasonable. There is a
This shopping place is nice. It actually has a canal flowing through the shopping center. Huge Muji and many many other shops. Easy parking too. Love it!

There are numerous restaurants and shops but most impressive was the ramen stadium. Also there is a good place called bear hug that one can get Japanese style massage. A complete shopping complex for the whole family.

This is the suitable place for find meal on lunch or dinner I'm not sure for breakfast many choice of restaurant you got here and the price really friendly and the store you find such kind like uniqlo, zara, hm n another europe brand but not the luxury one

We walked to the Kushida shrine from Hakata and found the Canal city on our way there. Canal city is a complex of department stores built on two sides of an artificial canal. It looked so muh beautiful in evening time with water music show. I would suggest spending some time
Great shop selection over several floors and lots of food places to eat. Crepes especially good. Easy to access and plenty to keep you busy.
Great place to chill out around the muji coffee place and a Must go place if you like Ramen. You can find all the Famous Ramen at one place , go to the top floor!

The shopping mall has so much to offer. It includes many kinds of stores like clothes, fragrances, suitcases, sports, cinemas, cosmetics, restaurants, animation-related and so on. I believe people who love shopping may spend lots of time here. It took me two hours just to

We walked from Tenjin and took us about twenty minutes. There are lots of shops, with a Cold Stone Creamery at level 2 to let the kids have their ice cream and waffle. Ramen stadium is worth checking out.

This is a good place to shop and eat with wide variety of food. Ramen Stadium, which consists of individual stalls which serve ramen from different regions of Japan can be found here. There are two hotels in here, Grand Hyatt and Washington Hotel, very convenient to get to
Serene city set in a busting pace. Heaps of night life & the atmosphere is very colourful. Easy to get around too.
The world starts to look the same everywhere. This ace is just a shopping mall and nothing that Singapore, Kuala Lumpur et al doesn't have
Canal city is where your u find the best ramen, beef and sushi restaurants. We spent an evening there and was quite impressed with the variety of shops they had there. Even had a men's fashion floor.

It took me around 15 minutes to walk from JR Hakata City to Canal City Hakata, At the entrance of Canal City Hakata, you can see a big Uniqlo. You are recommended to see water + light show under Canal Mirai Christmas Tree 2015 with Micheal Jackson's song at 7pm, 8pm, 9pm and

I was put off by some of the previous reviews. But it was so close to our accommodation that I went anyway. It's a medium priced mall with an excellent selection of shops and easy to navigate. Tax free shopping for visitors. Plenty of restaurants inside and close by.

For those of you, like I was, wondering about staying near Canal City which is a huge shopping mall. I discovered that the South Building of CC and Grand Hyatt is across the river from the red light district. Although I didn't see any ladies standing around since its cold. From
There are lots of food and store here. You can spend almost an afternoon here browsing through the stores and restaurants. The fountain perform water dancing. it's beautiful and worth to see

We stayed at the Grand Hyatt which is attached to the Canal City Hakata mall. It has a nice range of shops and restaurants and we have been spoiled for choice. This is a great option for families, as there's a Disney and Sanrio shop. There are also flagship Uniqlo, H&M and Zara

Light decorations welcome Christmas that attracts shoppers. Some cheap sales going on for all ages. Duty-free pharmaceutical shop mostly Japan-made at b1, really worth the visit so don't forget your passport for rebates.
It is more for the shopping and finding a place of refuge from the cold outside. Food wise is not fantastic. Nevertheless, a good place to hang out at night.

The complex is actually very lovely to walk around, and is split into 5 parts for each cardinal direction and a central walkway. To walk around the shops you are mostly outside, but it is covered so rain isn't much of a problem, but there are a large selection here so that you

Visited Hakata for the ramen. After sticking around the station, I figured the closest place to roam while the rain poured was Canal City. Lots of shops, architecture is kind of dated (except for the newer building which has Uniqlo, which kind of clashes with the old building).

Modern architecture building with shopping mall, restaurant and hotel. This place is packed with several shops from souveniers, home decoration, cloths, restaurants and toys. If you are a fan of either Muji and Gunplas, I would highly recommend this place. The Muji store is so
Nothing spectacular. Has a combination of outdoor and indoor areas, with a host of domestic and international brands, nothing a mall of this size will not carry.
For most westerners it's just another shopping centre with a slightly different feel but food can be found better and cheaper in the many local restaurants and even street found next to the canal.
Nothing more than a shopping mall. It's a modern building with global brand shops, nothing of Japanese flavor. A place you can purchase stuffs, enjoy the fountain show.

There is a big shopping mall in Hakata. However, i found that it's close so early for the shops around 9 pm. and some shop have limited time for tax free (eg. No later than 8 pm) so i have to pay it with tax due to i get back to Hakata late. If you really want to shop. i

Recently I visited Canal City, the first time in 5 years. Just as pretty as ever, all the stores you could ever want to visit, and the staff are friendly and helpful. As a guest house operator in Fukuoka, I recommend all my guests visit Canal City.
A good selection of restaurants in a smart setting. We actually intended to eat at the yattai stands on the island, but they were too busy so we were happy to find this food center

The Gap and Uniglo shops here are one of the larger ones. For example, Uniglo spans three floors in the front block, and there is a Zara opposite as well. On weekends, the place is buzzing and there are usually performances in the water fountain area near the Grand Hyatt

This is an amazing shopping complex, with all brand name stores, food court, a music fountain and a plaza for various performances. The Muji there is especially huge, and is the biggest I have seen in Japan. Its so big they have a space for holding lectures. Must visit.
If you're in to shopping, it's great. I liked going at night, it's all decorated for Halloween (in Oct.) ant there's an hourly lightshow. Very calm, beautiful by the water!

Day 1: Gion As I was not able to get accommodation in Hakata, Gion was the next alternative. It turned out to be not a bad choice at all. Daiwa Roynet, with its decent sized bed and room, was just one stop away from Hakata Station and one-minute walk from Gion Subway. It
Easy to find using the metro and a little walk. Lots of shops, very much market style. Many selling thecsame product. Worth a visit though

If you're looking for something original i don't think this will be the right place, its like any other big shopping mall in the world :) but if you're looking to shop for international products then this is the place

We were staying at the Grand Hyatt and this large mall was connected by a walkway. The stores are spread over several floors and are mainly accessed from outdoor entrances. Since it is brutally hot and humid, in July, just wandering around will make you break a very heavy

It's all under 1 roof and it's a huge place. But there's nothing more that I find interesting there. Food from the ramen stadium is gimmicky and not nice for a city known for its ramen. The nursing room was located in the loo and it is the worst that I have came across in this
Restaurants and tax free stores might be suit for rush tourists but nothing special to see or visit. Most goods are made in China and only few in Japan or suitable as souvenirs.
Nice place, full of restaurants, brand shops. and other attractions. it's close to Hakata Sta, 15mins walking distance and about 25mins to tenjin.

We tried exploring Fukuoka. However, when walked towards the center, we came across Canal City. We entered this strange looking building only to find out that it was very big. There are many shops but what really grabbed our attention was the performances. There was a band

Nice ambience with the canal surrounding the mall. Many shops like Disney Store, Agnes B etc and some local stores. There is a hotel at the mall and many eating places and souvenir shops as well. Good to pay the mall a visit, wide variety of merchandise.

Spent some time wandering around Canal City when we had some time to kill before we could check into our nearby ryokan. Nice shopping center with Japanese and foreign brands, connected to Hyatt Hotel. Go eat at Ramen (Raumen) Stadium of you want to try a variety of ramen from
Great place for shoppers. Has a wide variety of international stores like Zara and H&M as well as local stores. Great food too. Huge place and very clean.

We were walking near the Canal City first day when we arrived Fukuoka. There are a few hotels right below Canal City but we found this mall rather boring. The food hall in the basement was a bit quiet and the shops are mostly chain stores. If you want serious shopping, I'd

Just a 10 minute walk from JR Hakata Station. A great place for shopping, especially the 3rd floor with a great sports selection and range. There's also a section for only-made-in-Japan stuff and another section for all character-based and anime-based merchandise! The 5th

Huge multi-building multi-floor shopping complex connected by a series of pedestrian bridges, featuring fountains and a canal that separates it from Grand Hyatt hotel. Can get confusing for the first time visitor. Plenty of branded shopping (e.g. Bershka, Disney Store, H&M,

Here we can find so many Shops with Branded Stuff and there are Grand Hyatt Hotel in attach to This Shopping Mall. They have Indoor & Outdoor Shops. The Building Divide into 3 part : Grand Building, South & North Building, so it's a big shopping Centre. They also have Musical

Great mall with lots going on. I don't think the canal conept loks old at all, I think it's quite pretty. The fountain show is pretty cool too. Nice place to come in an enjoy AC on a hot summer day. Plus a lot of sales at the stores are enticing too (I like Uniqlo most). But

Lot's of fun, food and shopping. Great shopping arcade with numerous shops and restaurants. The facade is built around a "canal" which holds water park/playground and five-story water show. Restaurants on on floor 3 and 4 and offer a wide variety of options. There are U.S.

It was raining whole day when I came. Many shops selling ladies items. Bought a Snoopy lunch time bag (for my spouse). Many tourists too, as it seemed that they were from tour group given free time to explore this City.
Nice place to spend a rainy day (or a sunny day if you are a shoppeholic) Funny fountain show every hour. Good restaurants

Easily reached from Nakasu-Kawabata (leave from exit 5, wander down through the old Kamikawabata Machi market (with some interesting shops), past the Kushida Jinja, and you're then being signposted toward Canal City with a bit of luck. Very scenic for a mall, with water features

I read a lot of reviews about Canal City being dated and boring etc. It's actually a pretty cool place to visit. Yes the whole canal/fountain theme may be a bit old, but the place still has plenty of character. The fountain display is nice and there's a fantastic bar right

The place is near the Hakata bus station and can be quite difficult to find as its facade looks much different from the tourist pamphlets. There are about 5 floors and every floor is crowed with shoppers. The main attraction here is of course the 8 ramen restaurants on the 5th

The layout is interesting enough to make you wander on different levels. Water arrangements make it cooler than the air temperature. It hasn't got the air conditioned environment of a closed in mall so it more eco friendly. Ice sculptures so the kids can cool their hands.

I love this mall. I think the layout is interesting, built on a semicircle facing a hotel, with a little canal between. Twice an hour we can enjoy a water show, and frequent entertainers, often musicians, also comedians, dancers, and general entertainment. We've loved all the

This is a pretty typical shopping mall by the river. It is huge with a major hotel, many restaurants, cafes and departmental stores. On the top floor is a games area and a number of Ramen and noodle restaurants ala ramen street at Tokyo station. The hotel has an oyster

If you're looking for shopping Canal City is for you. Really though it is just like any urban mall. It has a few glitzy features but it's for shopping, not a tourism destination. As a mall it is good, with a wide selection of stores.

We wanted to visit the raumen stadium on the 5th floor of Canal City, which is famous for several ramen stalls. Our two favourites were the Hakata and Sapporo ramen, with the Hakata version using thinner noodles. Both were delicious, and the different broths were complex and
You can do everything in this mall, cinemas, amusement center, good restaurants, numerous shops and theater and Broadway shows. highly recommended.

It's conveniently connected between several buildings that include hotels and shopping malls. They provide hourly water show accompanied by music (not always live) and other shows including acrobats and musicians. From massage to food and shopping, it provides pretty much all

Located next to the Grand Hyatt Hotel, it offers great shopping and dining outlets. The canals also offer a picturesque setting and everything is indoors so you are not exposed to the elements. Many of the outlets open late and you could be spending too much time here without

Big and nice shopping mall. On the top floor there is a ramen stadium with all sorts of ramen stands. On the bottom floor there is a mini Bellagio fountain with music that plays on the hour. All to make your experience here the best

Yes it is just a shopping mall with fountains, but the fountains are very pretty and the whole place lights up with beautiful pink fairy lights at night, great if your hotel is local and you're looking for something to do. The centre itself is huge, with a very diverse
Although it's just a huge shopping complex, there's a variety of shops and eateries--fun place to be if you have free time to spare!

Without knowing how the mall is actually like, tourists may be attracted to Canal City Hakata simply by the word 'canal'. In fact, the so-called 'canals' are little rivers and fountains within a shopping complex and you don't have any chance to go there by boat. Therefore, I

This place has a great variety of shops, resturants and much more. I think it is a little overrated, at the end of the day it is just one big shopping complex, but if thats what you're after I can't deny it has a lot to offer. There was a great Italian place that

A charming mall in a beautiful street. The main attraction is the ramen stadium. if you like ramen, they offer a huge selection of different styles of miso, udon and korean ramen. Most restaurants have English menu. The architectural style of the mall is very interesting, you
A huge shopping mall with artificial canal. Ramen stadium on 5th floor of the canal city was good to have a ramen from different region.
Nothing much in this mall, what are here can be found anywhere else. Structure is confusing with the different wing. Musical fountain is not too bad, intriguing for kids.

This is a huge mall in the city centre with a few towers. Many shops selling shoes and clothing. If you have limited time, this is a place to see many brands under one roof. I prefer the shopping experience at Marinoa City Fukuoka, but that's further away from the city centre
A short walk from the Nakasu Island after dinner at the yatai stalls located along the river. Wide variety of shopping brands to choose from.

If you're not really into ramen, there's not much reason to visit Canal City. It's a rather dated shopping complex, which I suppose, must have seen more glamourous times. Compared to the other malls in Tenjin, this seems like a trip back to the 1990s.

It is just a big shopping mall. It seems extremely popular with PRC tourists. Many of the shop assistants are chinese, and signages in chinese were everywhere. I think the Tenjin area is more interesting, with more variety of outlets and departmental stores in close proximity.
lanes/alleys of shops and restaurants, nothing really interesting I would say. Go there only if you stay near there, really nothing special.

Shop, dine, watch a movie, - you can do it all here. Canal City is a large mall in Fukuoka and you can spend whole day here. It is just a 10 minute walk from Tenjin station. Outside you can find the Nakasu-Kabawata shopping arcade and the Kushida Shrine.

Bread lovers listen here, you will love dining at 'Bistro 309 Yoshoku Grill' at Basement floor as they serve freshly baked variety of breads with food like the absolutely yummy hamburger steak so moist and tasty served in a hot pan. Lots of shops mainly overseas brands. Down

what i like most is the ramen stadium on top, which have 8 famous ramen around Japan, tried the Sapporo Ramen Daichi, it was excellent! waited there for 30 mins during 14:30 hours. there is a big daizo store that sells brand names like Hermes. other than that are usual

This is an enormous shopping mall, supposedly largest in japan with 2.5M sq.ft retail space. To really look thru all the shops, u need at least a whole day. Food outlets aplenty but since we visited on a national holiday it was packed n we ended up eating not what we wanted.
Some interesting architecture, but it's a large mall. The musical water fountain show was the highlight.
At the end of the day it's just a shopping mall. The most interesting thing is the Ramen Stadium on the 5th floor.

While it's arguably Fukuoka's nicest and fanciest and biggest shopping mall, for most westerners it'll just be another shopping centre - and the food is much better and cheaper in the many local shops in and around the city.
This place is great to wonder around if you've got time to kill or want a quick bite. There is a ramen stadium that's a little difficult to find but well worth it.
very big and sophisticated shopping mall. You can find big brand name shops inside this mall. If you need cheper souvenirs or something, you shold try other areas.

This is a famous shpping mall in Fukuoka city. Compared with other shopping malls, this is located in the center of the city and especially close to Hakata station. Besides, it is convenient for foreigners to communicates with shop staffs in English. There is some shows for

I really liked this place. The building in itself is really beautiful and there are a lot of animations all around the place. In summer you can see the kids playing with the fountains ! On the last floor you also have a "ramen street" where you can taste all the ramens in Kyushu

There are the favourites including Uniqlo, Muji a very large store filled with furnishings products too, H&M, Bliss point, Agnes b, Daiso, etc. There are lots of food options including a Ramen Stadium with ramen from different parts of Japan, a steak restaurant serving good
Lotsa of shops and eating places. Enough to fill up your day or maybe even the second day. Variety of shops are good mix and very clean and nice place to go even with kids.
Not specific Japanese, like a US mall, but very good food department down below.... Nike, Victorinox, all the stuff you can buy at home...
I liked the style and architecture of this area. Great photo opportunities. Very clean. Numerous, varied paths to take, you can get lost here!

There is not much to see or do in Fukuoka so we ended up having tea and coffee at Muji in the last floor of this mall. There is nothing interesting about this mall. Even the architecture is bad. We found a good "French" bakery on the 1st floor where we bought some croissants.

Do not go there if you are on budget. I went there on July and everything was sales! EVERY SHOPS! It's big and have plenty of shops to choose. There''s Yatai (food stalls) which is sell famous Fukuoka Ramen.

just a shopping mall where you can find anything you want. They have nice Ramen( noddles) shop in the basement as well as in the ramen street in 4th or 5th floor. (I forgot). Most of the things selling there are over my budget.
This shopping area is fabulous, especially so when it's sale time. All kinds of stores to explore n pretty good quality everywhere. Also has good restaurants n good food!
This place is fine if you want trendy brand-name clothes and fashion, but otherwise not much there. A few cheaper stores in the basement.

Visited Fukuoka in May (2014) for 3 days and stayed at Washington Hotel located in the canal city. Really nice shopping area with lots of places to relax and quite the colorful architecture. Would go back again!

Fukuoka is a department store haven. Canal City had tons of fun shops to go in. We found a toy shop full of our favorite Japanese characters for our little one. This is also very near the canal where there is some fabulous street food.

Maybe it just seems like the Japanese love to eat and shop all the time. There were many cute shops that sold a lot of goods that Hakatans love. Watching the children at the water zone was immensely entertaining.

Family traveling with 2 girls. 9 & 12: We stayed at the Grand Hyatt connected to Canal City. We enjoyed shopping, playing and dining here. There were sales in all stores (August). Our girls enjoyed the hourly water show, Moomin Cafe, and the photo booths / arcade in Taito

It's a teens target shopping centre(?) not too much big brand here, it was suitable for teenagers i think. Big sale here (Before Aug), and you may get discount more than in the outlet. Please give 1 day here for shopping :)

My wife and I went to canal city as it was close by our hotel. There are many shops to browse through and some quite nice eating places. I went first to Starbucks coffee as there are not so many places with decent coffee. I went shopping in particular for a sports shop which we
Good place to rest your feet, eat and shop. Large Muji and Uniqlo stores inside. Nothing much for me.
Nice shopping place ! However, it takes 20 minutes walk from hakata station to Canal City.

my daughter fell in love with this mall, we had to go twice but still didn't get to go to all the shops we wanted. there is a daiso dollar (100 yen) store which is good to get small cheap gifts and candy. An amazing shop that has a lot of toys and collectables of popular
Its having branded showrooms and high end brands. The canal water is very clean and the malls itself is very huge compared to the standard.
its a nice shopping complex. food and lots of nice clothing stores.can tell why it was one of the best shopping malls back in the day
Everything you can think of and living in Korea I was so glad in canal city to see next and Zara nice food outlets as well and nice area just to walk around

Interesting form of building! Easy access from hakata station and subway in walking distance. There is ramen stadium for ramen lover! Many more restaurant and theme cafe, Moomin cafe. Canal city is just next to Grand hyatt. Each hour (i think) there will be fountain show

Canal City is within easy walking distance from the Crowne Plaza Hotel. There is Ramen Stadium there, definitely worth a visit

Shops close early in Japan, and Canal City is no exception. However, it's within walking distance of Hakata Station (where our hotel was), so it was a very convenient place for us to do some simple shopping and have our dinner/supper. Plenty of food choices, and they stay open

Great building area to check out - exciting architecture and mega amounts of shops. Close to if not quite in the central Hakata area. Well worth visiting - they have movie theatres in the complex too, with loads of movies both in English and Japanese to choose from.
on 5th floor have place like food court but they only sell Ramen noodle. all shop there is one of the best Ramen from Ramen Champion in Japan

We had some time to kill before going to the airport so we stowed our suitcases in the Hakata train station lockers and hoofed it a mile to Canal City. The Mall is huge, 3-4 buildings that do not necessarily interconnect so make sure you use the interactive maps (in English) to

Put on your walking shoes cause this mall is 5 floors huge! Nice water attraction in the middle, gives you an excuse to sit and rest your feet for a few minutes. Visit raumen stadium, lots of places to choose from.

If you are from Hawaii and like saimin, wait until you see this place. You might not eat anywhere else for a couple days! Get your Hakata Ramen with all the optional trimmings, and then try some of the others to taste the various differences.
Canal City Hakata is another big shopping mall. In terms of shopping, nothing is particularly good. Some good points are: External artistic design + Water Fountain Show
This was pretty much a mall with shops and restaurants. Some good places to shop and eat. Nothing spectacular. The water fountain show was pretty cool to watch for a bit.

This shopping mall is right next to Grand Hyatt and my children enjoyed eating and shopping at this mall. They also enjoyed playing at the arcade on 5th floor. There is a ramen stadium which gave us a lot of choice. Water fountain show was fun which comes on every hour.
The shops are a big high-end and eclectic but the scenic design is worth a few photos. Ramen stadium is a must-visit to try the authentic local and regional ramen selections.
This huge complex contains all variety of shops: I enjoyed very much the ramen restaurants and the sushi shops.

The shops and brands at this mall are suitable for younger person. No need to make a trip just for this mall.

Both American and Japanese stores. A multiple level shopping mall with hotels connected. Would be a great place to waste a day or to stay out of the rain.

Fine enough to walk around, if you still have time before departure, just 15 mins from JP Railway Station. All the brands could also be found in Hong Kong. Preferable to focus the time and $$$ in JR Hakata Station Mall (Amu Plaza and Tokyo Hands....etc.)

Canal City Hakata , a place for entertaiment , shopping , dinning . There is a small lake arround with fontains wich are dancing same in Barcelona , many restaurants and great place for cildrens . Also is conected with the Grand Hyatt Hotel , where you can find what do you want

Great shops, nice atmosphere. Just leave breadcrumbs where you walk so you'll find your way back from where you came from.
The location is still convenient with lots of shops downstairs but i am not sure if there are always have band to sing for the whole day and seems like a bit noisy....

Was the right thing at the right time for me, but a quality shopping mall nevertheless. Fashion is mostly for young rather than mature people, but I found many items that I fell in love for, that I felt I would not find elsewhere. Lots of foreign and japanese brands. Modern

We spent quite a few hours at this shopping complex. My husband just wanted to have a coffee, check the emails and relax. My daughters and I just wanted to shop. Eldest daughter went off on her own, but my 23 andl 14 year old daughters and I stayed together. We lovedthrough

I wouldn't recommend this to anyone who doesn't like shopping. Also, you can find many of the brands in Tenjin or department stores, but you have to know where to go. Here, it's under one roof. There's a pokemon centre for kids and some great restaurants.
the information center was very kind, there are introducing the local area and tell us how to go as well. every 21:00 o'clock has fountain show on the first floor stage.
Very big sopping complex, lots of restaurant , mainly Japanese food. Ramen stadium is must visit and enjoy very good ramen

Easy, lots of choices including pick any of the restaurant in the Centre. Easy access Bus 100 kept circulating, 100.00 Yen to Fukuoka city - Daimaru.... etc. Bring 2 pairs of spare legs as replacement. :)

Nice building, it appears at most of Fukuoka city brochure or guidebook. The stores inside are nothing special. Not a big loss to give a miss if running short of time in Fukuoka.
Awesome architecture and very unique. Went to dinner at one of the upper floor restaurants (sorry forgot the name - it was a long day ;-) the meal was superb too!

A great time was had by all, we stayed at thew Hyatt which is right there. The shops and resturants are expensive so bring plenty of Yen.
This is a shopping complex with a variety of shops. It is just about 15 minutes' walk from Hakata Station.

Wonderful place! There are numerous shops, restaurants, Ramen stadium, entertainment places including Theater. We enjoyed the performance "Sounds of Musics". Even if the weather in Fukuoka is rainy you may have a nice time visiting Canal City.
literally, thousands of stores, gastronomics, cinemas, two hotels, and an internal river,

usual mall attributes. Restaurants and lots of stores catering to women, mostly clothing. Not my thing
lots of shops and eating places. try ramen stadium. Clothing for the young

where you will find one of the local Starbucks for a Western breakfast and get a Japanese theme Park mall type experienced. Quite pretty at night
Great design and supposedly "green." But overall, just another mall in Japan.
Not a good shopping area at all. Try to avoid it under limited travelling time.

If traveling with kids, pretty excellent place to hang out, good combination of main street plus local stores
Good collection of western shops in one roof in Fukuoka.

google: Better to visit here at night as there are water shows happening (not sure about the schedule) at the fountain area and it is SO COOL. Interesting mall layout, might be confusing at times but the stores available are still nice and sufficient.
I just passed by there. Atmosphere of the mall was nice... There is some character... Not like most mall in Japan.
One of the better malls to visit in Fukuoka city. They have a pretty good cinema which includes IMAX and 4DX options if you are into that sort of thing.

very nice mall with lots of interesting shops and restaurants from the cheapest to the most expensive. there is also a water show every half hour. the outside garden is very nice, with moving water and lots of sittings.
Tourist must visit this place. It has many things to offer

Pretty unique shopping complex here in Fukuoka. Plenty of designer shops & fashion outlets, with a dedicated tax-free redemption counter for tourists.

As the name says the main theme of this mall is canal! So they have a canal!! So just walking around this mall is nice! Enjoy!!

Don't worry if you missed the first one, they have the performance through the night. We were lucky as we caught the Christmas version of it.

This place was huge and had lots of stores and restaurants. The fountains were great for pictures. It was relaxing and entertaining, kids would enjoy watching the fountains. 

They have the evangelion store and they also have a disney store …

Such beautiful design. Standard shops mixed with cool creative places.

Worth a stop for anyone visiting the area.

Went to this mall to checkout Gundam Cafe and it didn't disappointment me. I also lost my head gear but was able to recover it to the information counter. A lot of shops you can visit and watch the fountain show at night
Good place. Special attraction is the musical fountain

Fine exclusive restaurants, shops, cafes, game center, cinemas & etc in the complex. Shoppers have a very wide …

Great outdoor indoor mall. Has a water musical show in the center and nice directory to show you the layout of the stores on each floors.
A great place to shop for branded goods. Once an impressive building located behind the great Hyatt hotel. Not really a must go place for visiting Fukuoka. Skip this if you are low on time.

Canal City Hakata (キャナルシティ博多) is a large shopping and entertainment complex in Fukuoka, Japan. Called the "city within the city,".

It’s aight. The fountain shows are neat, I suppose. Get your capitalist itch on you corporate shills.

Great place to shop. A bit confusing to get around, but lots to shop and see. Stuff for kids and adults a like. I'd probably go elsewhere for food if you want something more local, but lots to keep you occupied.
So many branded stores and restaurants all in one place! It's like Suntec City in Singapore but not as big. There's a light water show every few minutes to enjoy.
Shopping place for tourist! Great food great fun! There are 3 sections in the areas. Should come visit and 🛍 day
Huge mall that's definitely worth spending some time in. Lots of interesting stores, although a little bit like a maze

Great Ramen, got the lunch special which made it worth it, but prices are higher than normal apart from that.
The go-to in Fukuoka for shopping. Good range of outlets, tax free (I usually go Laox) and restaurants. Near another shopping street of mine, Kawabata Shotengai within walking distance.

Lots of shops both Japanese and Western brands.  There is a separate tax free counter in the first floor.  They do charge 1.5 percent for handling fee.  Lady manning the tax free counter is efficient.  They also have a tourist lounge where you can charge your phone.  They have ramen stadium in the 5th floor - lineups though.

Great shopping mall with anything that you could think of.  Too bad they close a little early though.  Once 9pm comes, nearly every store is closed.  There are a few restaurants and food venues on the first floor that will stay open a little later though.

Great one-stop shopping place. 
Stopped by during the rain and easily spent a couple hours over food and browsing.

Location is good, hotel is good, everything are so good. Stay at one place and you can buy everything  in one place.

Great place to shop for anything.  I even went to the IMAX theater there today. It was great outing.

there are many shopping mall with grand hyatt fukuoka.  You can see beautiful fountain light show.

The canal city is connected to the Hyatt Hotel and is nice for shopping, movies, and games.

very nice place! It is a very Big Mall. You will see an amazing Dancing fountain and light show at night. such a good experience. I Love it!

Loving because of only two shops.
Jump comics shop for souvenir and the Gunpla base shop!!!!

Beautiful shopping mall , they have 10 min shows water dancing and projections,) it worth it
Very good shipping mall in town,  you'll find a lot surprising
There are alot of stores to shop at and the water show is beautiful.

It's better than last year, especially I'm very glad seeing Hoshino's coffee. That's my favorite  coffee.
If you are in Hakata, I absolutely suggest one of those local hakata style tonkotsu ramen spots other than these franchises. Yet, ramen was good as usual and was a good experience.

It's a really nice shopping area, lots of construction so not full 5 stars. Nice water fountain show at 8:30pm when we were there.
Enjoyed shopping, loved the fountain show & atmosphere and food was great there!
Nice and have famous Gundam stall. Many choice stuff and brand product.

Loved the shops available in there especially the fan shops like evangelion , moomin, jump shop and many more .. the fountain show is lovely and a variety of restaurants

Overall not bad but didn't have the photo booth machine , so sad

The only shopping center I went through during my time in Japan. Its  nice to tug along in this area , its cheaper to shop here esp. when you need to  buy something to bring back home. My family and friends were so happy to have got one.

Visited in January 2020. Integrated shopping and entertainment complex comprising of around 250 shops, cafes and restaurants, a theater, game center, cinemas, two hotels and a canal running through the complex.

Great place for shopping! 
They got great selection of shops and you can put your bags and shopped items to the lockers.

text.wiki:
Fukuoka (福岡市, Fukuoka-shi, pronounced [ɸɯ̥kɯokaꜜɕi]) is the capital city of Fukuoka Prefecture, situated on the northern shore of the Japanese island of Kyushu. It is the most populous city on the island, followed by Kitakyushu. It is the largest city and metropolitan area west of Keihanshin. The city was designated on April 1, 1972, by government ordinance. Greater Fukuoka, with a population of 2.5 million people (2005 census), is part of the heavily industrialized Fukuoka–Kitakyushu zone.
As of 2015, Fukuoka is Japan's sixth largest city, having passed the population of Kobe. In July 2011, Fukuoka surpassed the population of Kyoto. Since the founding of Kyoto in 794, this marks the first time that a city west of the Kinki region has a larger population than Kyoto. In ancient times, however, the area near Fukuoka, the Chikushi region, was thought by some historians to have possibly been even more influential than the Yamato region.


== Pre-history ==
Exchanges from the continent and the Northern Kyushu area date as far back as Old Stone Age. It has been thought that waves of immigrants arrived in Northern Kyushu from mainland Asia. Several Kofun exist.


== History ==

Fukuoka was sometimes called the Port of Dazaifu (大宰府), 15 km (9 mi) southeast from Fukuoka. Dazaifu was an administrative capital in 663 A.D., but a historian proposed that a prehistoric capital was in the area. Ancient texts, such as the Kojiki, Kanyen (found in Dazaifu) and archaeology confirm this was a very critical place in the founding of Japan. Some scholars claim that it was the first place outsiders and the Imperial Family set foot, but like many early Japan origin theories, it remains contested. Central Fukuoka is sometimes still referred as Hakata which is the name of the central ward.
In 923, the Hakozaki-gū in Fukuoka was transferred from Daibu-gū in Daibu (大分), 16 km (10 mi) northeast from Dazaifu, the origin of Usa Shrine and established as a branch of the Usa Shrine at Fukuoka. In Ooho (大保), 15 km (9 mi) south from Dazaifu, there are remains of a big ward office with a temple, because in ancient East Asia, an emperor must have three great ministries (大宰, 大傳 and 大保). In fact, there is a record in Chinese literature that a king of Japan sent a letter in 478 to ask the Chinese emperor's approval for employing three ministries. In addition, remains of the Korokan (鴻臚館, Government Guest House) were found in Fukuoka underneath a part of the ruins of Fukuoka Castle.


=== Mongol invasions (1274–1281) ===

Kublai Khan of the Mongol Empire turned his attention towards Japan starting in 1268, exerting a new external pressure on Japan with which it had no experience. Kublai Khan first sent an envoy to Japan to make the Shogunate acknowledge Khan's suzerainty. The Kamakura shogunate refused. Mongolia repeatedly sent envoys thereafter, each time urging the Shogunate to accept their proposal, but to no avail.
In 1274, Kublai Khan mounted an invasion of the northern part of Kyushu with a fleet of 900 ships and 33,000 troops, including troops from Goryeo on the Korean Peninsula. This initial invasion was compromised by a combination of incompetence and severe storms. After the invasion attempt of 1274, Japanese samurai built a stone barrier 20 km (12 mi) in length bordering the coast of Hakata Bay in what is now the city of Fukuoka. The wall, 2–3 metres in height and having a base width of 3 metres, was constructed between 1276 and 1277, and was excavated in the 1930s.
Kublai sent another envoy to Japan in 1279. At that time, Hōjō Tokimune of the Hōjō clan (1251–1284) was the Eighth Regent. Not only did he decline the offer, but he beheaded the five Mongolian emissaries after summoning them to Kamakura. Infuriated, Kublai organized another attack on Fukuoka Prefecture in 1281, mobilizing 140,000 soldiers and 4,000 ships. The Japanese defenders, numbering around 40,000, were no match for the Mongols and the invasion force made it as far as Dazaifu, 15 km (9 mi) south of the city of Fukuoka. However, the Japanese were again aided by severe weather, this time by a typhoon that struck a crushing blow to the Mongolian troops, thwarting the invasion.
It was this typhoon that came to be called the Kamikaze (Divine Wind), and was the origin of the term Kamikaze used to indicate suicide attacks by military aviators of the Empire of Japan against Allied naval vessels during World War II.


=== Formation of the modern city (1889) ===

Fukuoka was formerly the residence of the powerful daimyō of Chikuzen Province, and played an important part in the medieval history of Japan. The renowned temple of Tokugawa Ieyasu in the district was destroyed by fire during the Boshin War of 1868. 
The modern city was formed on April 1, 1889, with the merger of the former cities of Hakata and Fukuoka. Historically, Hakata was the port and merchant district, and was more associated with the area's culture and remains the main commercial area today. On the other hand, the Fukuoka area was home to many samurai, and its name has been used since Kuroda Nagamasa, the first daimyō of Chikuzen Province, named it after his birthplace in Okayama Prefecture and the "old Fukuoka" is the main shopping area, now called Tenjin.
When Hakata and Fukuoka decided to merge, a meeting was held to decide the name for the new city. Hakata was initially chosen, but a group of samurai crashed the meeting and forced those present to choose Fukuoka as the name for the merged city. However, Hakata is still used to refer to the Hakata area of the city and, most famously, to refer to the city's train station, Hakata Station, and dialect, Hakata-ben.


=== 20th century ===
1903: Fukuoka Medical College, a campus associated with Kyoto Imperial University, is founded. In 1911, the college is renamed Kyushu Imperial University and established as a separate entity.
1910: Fukuoka streetcar service begins. (The service ran until 1979.)
1929: Flights commence along the Fukuoka-Osaka-Tokyo route.
1945: Fukuoka was firebombed on June 19, with the attack destroying 21.5 percent of the city's urban area.
1947: First Fukuoka Marathon.
1951: Fukuoka airport opens.
1953: Fukuoka Zoo opens.
1975: The city absorbed the town of Sawara.
1981: Subway commences service.
1988: Osaka's pro baseball team, the Nankai Hawks, are moved to Fukuoka and renamed the Fukuoka Daiei Hawks (renamed the Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks in 2004).
1989: Asian-Pacific Exposition is held.
1997: The 30th annual meeting of the Asian Development Bank was held in Fukuoka.


=== 21st century ===
2005: Fukuoka subway Nanakuma Line started operations.
2014: Selected as the National Strategic Zone for "global startups & job creation" by the Japanese government.
2020: City affected by Covid-19.


== Geography ==
Fukuoka is bordered on three sides by mountains, surrounds Hakata Bay and opens on the north to the Genkai Sea.
It is located 1,100 km (684 mi) from Tokyo.


=== Climate ===
Fukuoka has a humid subtropical climate (Köppen: Cfa), hot and humid summers, and relatively mild winters. The city also sees on average about 1,600 mm (63 in) of precipitation per year, with a stretch of more intense precipitation between the months of June and September. Along with much of the prefecture, Fukuoka City has a moderate climate with an annual average temperature of 16.3 °C (61 °F), average humidity of 70% and 1,811 annual daylight hours. Roughly 40% of the year is cloudy.
Winter temperatures rarely drop below 0 °C (32 °F) and it rarely snows, though light rain does fall on most days if not as consistently as on the Sea of Japan side of Honshu. Spring is warm and sunnier, with cherry blossoms appearing in late March or early April. The rainy season (tsuyu) lasts for approximately six weeks through June and July, during which time the humidity is very high and temperatures hover between 25 °C (77 °F) and 30 °C (86 °F). Summers are humid and hot, with temperatures peaking around 37 °C (99 °F). Autumn, often considered to be Fukuoka's best season, is mild and dry, though the typhoon season runs between August and September.


=== Earthquakes ===

Fukuoka is not as seismically active as many other parts of Japan, but does experience occasional earthquakes. The most powerful recent earthquake registered a lower 6 of maximum 7 of the Japanese intensity scale and hit at 10:53 am local time on March 20, 2005, killing one person and injuring more than 400. The epicentre of the earthquake was in the Genkai Sea along a yet-undiscovered extension of the Kego fault that runs through the centre of Fukuoka. Genkai island, a part of Nishi-ku, was the most severely damaged by the earthquake and almost all island residents were forced to evacuate. Aftershocks continued intermittently throughout the following weeks as construction crews worked to rebuild damaged buildings throughout the city. Traditional Japanese houses, particularly in the areas of Daimyo and Imaizumi, were the most heavily damaged and many were marked for demolition, along with several apartment buildings. Insurance payments for damages were estimated at approximately 15.8 billion yen.A similar quake, with an intensity of 5+, also occurred one month later on April 20, 2005.
Fukuoka's major Kego fault runs northwest to southeast, roughly parallel to Nishitetsu's Ōmuta train line, and was previously thought to be 22 km (14 mi) long. It is estimated to produce earthquakes as strong as magnitude 7 at the focus approximately once every 15,000 years. If the focus were located at a depth of 10 km (6 mi), this would translate to an earthquake of a lower-6 magnitude (similar to the March 20, 2005 earthquake) in downtown Fukuoka if it were the epicenter. The probability of an earthquake along the known length of the Kego fault occurring within 30 years was estimated at 0.4% prior to the March 20, 2005 earthquake, but this probability has been revised upwards since. Including the new extension out into the Genkai Sea, the Kego fault is now thought to be 40 km (25 mi) long.
Following reports that the city has only prepared for earthquakes up to a magnitude of 6.5, several strong aftershocks renewed fears that the quakes might cause the portion of the Kego fault that lies under the city to become active again, leading to an earthquake as big as, or bigger than, the March 20 quake.


== Wards ==
Fukuoka has 7 wards (ku).


== Demographics ==
As of November 2018, the city had an estimated population of 1,581,527 and a population density of 4,515.64 persons per km². The total area is 343.39 square kilometres (132.58 sq mi). Fukuoka is Japan's youngest major city and has Japan's fastest growing population. Between December 2012 and December 2017, the proportion of foreign-born residents increased faster than any other major city in Japan, including Tokyo.There were 171 homeless residents counted in 2018's annual survey, down from a high of 969 in 2009.


== Economy ==

Fukuoka is the economic center of the Kyushu region, with an economy largely focused on the service sector. It is also the largest startup city in Japan, and is the only economic zone for startups. They have various services for startups like startup visa, tax reduction, and free business consultations. Fukuoka has the highest business-opening rate in Japan. Large companies headquartered in the city include Iwataya and Kyushu Electric Power. Fukuoka is also the home of many small firms playing a supportive role in the logistics, IT, and high-tech manufacturing sectors. Most of the region's heavy manufacturing takes place in the nearby city of Kitakyushu.
The GDP in Greater Fukuoka, Fukuoka Metropolitan Employment Area, was US$101.6 billion in 2010. Fukuoka is the primary economic center of the Fukuoka-Kitakyushu metropolitan area, which is the 4th largest economy in Japan. As of 2014, the area's PPP-adjusted GDP is estimated to be larger than those of metropolitan areas such as Melbourne, Kuala Lumpur, Lima, Vienna, Barcelona and Rome.Several regional broadcasters are based in the city, including Fukuoka Broadcasting Corporation, Kyushu Asahi Broadcasting, Love FM, RKB Mainichi Broadcasting, and Television Nishinippon Corporation.
The port of Hakata and Fukuoka Airport also make the city a key regional transportation hub. Fukuoka houses the headquarters of Kyushu Railway Company (JR Kyushu) and Nishi-Nippon Railroad. Air Next, a subsidiary of All Nippon Airways, is headquartered in Hakata-ku; prior to its dissolution, Harlequin Air was also headquartered in Hakata-ku.Fukuoka has its own stock exchange, founded in 1949. It is one of six in Japan.Fukuoka is one of the more affordable cities in Japan. Compared to New York City, rents are ~80% lower, restaurants are ~50% cheaper, and groceries are ~5% more expensive. 


== Culture ==
Fukuoka was selected as one of Newsweek's 10 "Most Dynamic Cities" in its July 2006 issue. It was chosen for its central Asian location, increasing tourism and trade, and a large increase in volume at its sea and airport. Fukuoka has a diverse culture and a wide range of cultural attractions.
In its July/August 2008 issue, Monocle selected Fukuoka as number 17 of the "Top 25 liveable cities". It was chosen for excellent shopping, outstanding food, good transport links, good museums, "a feeling of openness in its sea air", green spaces and because it is friendly, safe, clean and close to the rest of East Asia. The same survey in 2018 ranked Fukuoka at number 22.


=== Tourism ===

Fukuoka hosts more than 2 million foreign visitors annually, with the majority coming from neighboring South Korea, Taiwan and China. From the early 2010s Hakata became the beneficiary of significant growth in cruise ship tourism; particularly with visitors from China. After expansion and redevelopment of the Hakata Port international passenger ship terminal, the number of cruise ship port calls in 2016 is expected to exceed 400.Nearly ten thousand international students attend universities in or near the Fukuoka prefecture each year. Nearly 200 international conferences are held each year in Fukuoka.


==== Attractions ====

Sky Dream Fukuoka, in Fukuoka's western ward, was one of the world's largest Ferris wheels at a height of 120 meters. It was closed on September 2009. The surrounding shopping center, Marinoa City Fukuoka, still attracts millions of visitors each year. Other shopping centers that attract tourists include Canal City, JR Hakata City, and Hakata Riverain.Fukuoka Castle, located adjacent to Ohori Park in Maizuru Park, features the remaining stone walls and ramparts left after a devastating fire during the upheaval of the Meiji Restoration. It has now been preserved along with some reconstructed prefabricate concrete towers constructed during the 1950s and 1960s, when there was a trend across Japan to rebuild damaged castles as tourist attractions. Ōhori Park is also the location of one of Fukuoka City's major art galleries.
There are many temples with long histories including Tōchō-ji, Hakozaki Shrine, Kashii shrine, and Jōten-ji.
The Marine Park Uminonakamichi is located on a narrow cape on the northern side of the Bay of Hakata. The park has an amusement park, petting zoo, gardens, beaches, a hotel, and a large marine aquarium which opened in 1989.For tourists from other parts of Japan, local foods such as mentaiko, Hakata ramen and motsunabe are associated with Fukuoka. Yatai (street stalls) serving ramen can be found in Tenjin and Nakasu most evenings.
Fukuoka Tower is near the beach in Seaside Momochi, a development built for the 1989 Asia-Pacific Exhibition. The older symbol of the city, Hakata Port Tower is next to the international ferry terminal and is free to enter.
Itoshima, to the west of Fukuoka city, has recently become a very popular tourist destination.  There are many beaches along the coast, notably Futamigaura beach, where there is a famous Shinto shrine in the ocean, and Keya beach, which hosts the annual Sunset Live festival every September. Inland, there is the Shingon Buddhist temple called Raizan Sennyoji, where there are many Buddhist statues and stunning autumn foliage.The Buddhist Nanzoin temple is located in Sasaguri, just east of Fukuoka. It is claimed to be the largest statue of a reclining Buddha in the world.
There is a newly opened Kyushu National Museum in nearby Dazaifu.


=== Museums ===

Fukuoka Art Museum – In Ohori Park; contains a wide selection of contemporary and other art from around the world, including works by Mark Rothko, Roy Lichtenstein, and Salvador Dalí.
Fukuoka Asian Art Museum – contains art from various countries of Asia.
Fukuoka City Museum – displays a broad range of items from the region's history, including a spectacular gold seal.
Fukuoka Oriental Ceramics Museum
Fukuoka Prefectural Museum of Art
Genko Historical Museum (元寇史料館, Museum of the Mongol Invasion) – In Higashi Koen (East Park); displays Japanese and Mongolian arms and armor from the 13th century as well as paintings on historical subjects. Open on weekends.
Hakata Machiya Folk Museum – Dedicated to displaying the traditional ways of life, speech, and culture of the Fukuoka region.The Fukuoka Asian Culture Prize was established to honor the outstanding work of individuals or organizations in Asia.


=== Festivals ===

Fukuoka is home to many festivals (matsuri) that are held throughout the year. Of these, the most famous are Hakata Dontaku and Hakata Gion Yamakasa.


==== Yamakasa ====
Yamakasa (山笠), held for two weeks each July, is Fukuoka's oldest festival with a history of over 700 years. The festival dates back to 1241 when a priest called Shioichu Kokushi saved Hakata from a terrible plague by being carried around the city on a movable shrine and throwing water. Teams of men (no women, except small girls, are allowed), representing different districts in the city, commemorate the priest's route by racing against the clock around a set course carrying on their shoulders floats weighing several thousand pounds. Participants all wear shimekomi (called fundoshi in other parts of Japan), which are traditional loincloths.
Each day of the two-week festival is marked by special events and practice runs, culminating in the official race that takes place the last morning before dawn. Tens of thousands line the streets to cheer on the teams. During the festival, men can be seen walking around many parts of Fukuoka in long happi coats bearing the distinctive mark of their team affiliation and traditional geta sandals. The costumes are worn with pride and are considered appropriate wear for even formal occasions, such as weddings and cocktail parties, during the festival.

		


==== Hakata Dontaku ====
Hakata Dontaku (博多どんたく) is held in Fukuoka City on May 3 and 4. Boasting over 800 years of history, Dontaku is attended by more than 2 million people, making it the festival with the highest attendance during Japan's Golden Week holidays. During the festival, stages are erected throughout downtown for traditional performances and a parade of floats is held. The full name is Hakata Dontaku Minato Matsuri.The festival was stopped for seven years during the Meiji era. Since it was restarted in the 12th year of the Meiji era it has been known as Hakata Dontaku.


=== Music ===
Notable musical names in J-pop include Ayumi Hamasaki (allegedly Japan's richest woman), singer-songwriter Ringo Shiina, hugely popular singer-songwriter duo Chage & Aska, singer-songwriter Eri Nobuchika, Misia, Masamune Kusano and Yui. During the 1970s, local musicians prided themselves on their origins and dubbed their sound, Mentai Rock.
Morning Musume 6th generation member Reina Tanaka was also born here in 1989 along with 9th generation member Erina Ikuta in 1997.
Dominican songwriter and singer Juan Luis Guerra pays homage to the city in his bachata song Bachata en Fukuoka (2010).
HKT 48 have their own Theater at Nishitetsu Hall.


== Transport ==

Fukuoka is served by Fukuoka Airport, the San'yō Shinkansen and the Kyushu Shinkansen high-speed rail line and other JR Kyushu trains at Hakata Station and by ferry. JR Kyushu and a Korean company operate hydrofoil ferries (named Beetle and Kobee) between Hakata and Busan, South Korea. The city has three subway lines: the Kūkō Line, the Hakozaki Line, and the newest one, Subway Nanakuma Line, opened on February 2, 2005. A private railway line, run by Nishitetsu is also heavily used and connects the downtown area of Tenjin to the city of Ōmuta.


== Sports ==

Fukuoka is the home of the Fukuoka SoftBank Hawks, one of Japan's top professional baseball teams. Threatened with bankruptcy and forced by its creditors to restructure, former owner Daiei sold the Hawks to Softbank Capital in 2004.
Fukuoka is home to a professional football team, Avispa Fukuoka.
Annual sporting events include:

The All Japan Judo Category Championships are held in early April.
The Kyushu ekiden, beginning in Nagasaki and ending in Fukuoka, the world's longest relay race, held in October. (Defunct)
The November tournament of professional Sumo is held at the Fukuoka Kokusai Center.
Fukuoka International Open Marathon Championships, with start/finish at Heiwadai Athletic Stadium, held on the 1st Sunday of December.Fukuoka has hosted the following sporting events:

1983 Asian Volleyball Championship for Women
1995 Summer Universiade
1997 Pan Pacific Swimming Championships
1998 Women's Volleyball World Championship
1999 Asian Basketball Championship
2001 World Aquatics Championships.
2006 IAAF World Cross Country Championships.
Fukuoka International Women's Judo Championships from 1983 to 2006.
2013-14 Grand Prix of Figure Skating Final

== International relations ==
Fukuoka has nine sister cities.
The city established the Asian Pacific City Summit in 1994. It consists of 26 Asia-Pacific cities.
